questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with a painful hip after a fall. The X-ray shows a fracture of the femoral neck. What is the most important complication to be aware of?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Avascular necrosis

 

Option A)

 

  • Avascular necrosis (AVN) is a critical complication of femoral neck fractures.
  • The blood supply to the femoral head primarily comes from the medial and lateral femoral circumflex arteries, which can be disrupted by the fracture.
  • Pathophysiology:
  • When the blood supply is compromised, the cells in the femoral head die due to lack of oxygen and nutrients.
  • This leads to bone resorption and, ultimately, collapse of the femoral head.
  • Risk Factors:
  • AVN is more common in fractures that are displaced or in younger patients, as they tend to have more vigorous physical activity post-injury.
  • AVN can develop weeks to months after the fracture, often leading to long-term complications such as hip pain and early osteoarthritis.

 

Other options:

 

Option B) Infection: Infection is a potential complication but is less common in isolated femoral neck fractures unless there are open fractures or associated surgical interventions. Open fractures or surgery increase the risk of infection, particularly in the context of implanted hardware. Symptoms of infection may include fever, increasing pain, swelling, and discharge at the surgical site. Infections may require antibiotic therapy and, in severe cases, surgical intervention to debride infected tissue.

 

Option C) Malunion: Malunion refers to improper healing of the fracture, leading to a misalignment of the bone. Malunion can result in persistent pain, functional limitations, and abnormal biomechanics in the hip joint. Factors such as inadequate stabilization during the healing process, improper reduction, or non-compliance with rehabilitation can contribute to this complication. Malunion may necessitate corrective surgery, which can involve osteotomy or revision surgery.

 

Option D) Neurovascular Injury: Neurovascular injury is a concern in any hip fracture but is generally less common compared to AVN. The injury can involve damage to the femoral nerve or blood vessels, potentially leading to complications like loss of sensation, motor function, or limb ischemia. Neurological and vascular assessments are crucial at the time of evaluation. Signs of injury might include altered sensation in the thigh or foot, or diminished pulse in the lower limb. If a neurovascular injury is identified, prompt surgical intervention may be necessary to restore blood flow or nerve function.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Avascular necrosis is the most critical complication of femoral neck fractures, particularly due to its high impact on long-term function and quality of life.
  • Early recognition and management of this complication are essential for improving patient outcomes.

choices.text: Anterior cervical discectomy and fusion (ACDF)

questions.text: What is the name of the procedure where a bone graft is taken from the iliac crest and used to fuse two vertebrae together?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Anterior cervical discectomy and fusion (ACDF)

 

Option D)

 

  • ACDF is a surgical procedure that combines two actions: first, the discectomy (removal of a herniated or degenerated disc) and then the fusion of the adjacent vertebrae using a bone graft, which can be taken from the iliac crest or another source.
  • The primary goal of ACDF is to relieve nerve compression and stabilize the cervical spine by fusing the vertebrae together, making this the correct answer in the context of your question.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Laminectomy: A laminectomy is a surgical procedure that involves the removal of the lamina, which is the back part of a vertebra. This operation is usually performed to relieve pressure on the spinal cord or nerves caused by conditions like herniated discs or spinal stenosis. It is primarily aimed at alleviating pain or neurological symptoms rather than fusing vertebrae together.

 

Option B) Discectomy: A discectomy is a surgical procedure that involves the removal of a herniated disc in the spine. This can relieve pressure on spinal nerves that may be causing pain, weakness, or numbness. Like a laminectomy, a discectomy is not intended for fusion but rather to address specific issues related to the intervertebral discs.

 

Option C) Bone Grafting:  Bone grafting is a procedure that involves transplanting bone tissue to repair or regenerate bone. This can be done using bone from the patient (autograft), a donor (allograft), or synthetic materials. While bone grafting can be a part of spinal fusion procedures, it is not a standalone procedure that specifically fuses vertebrae.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Regarding the procedure where a bone graft is used to fuse two vertebrae together is Anterior cervical discectomy and fusion (ACDF).

questions.text: A 45-year-old female with a history of long-term corticosteroid use presents with hip pain and limited range of motion. An MRI shows changes consistent with avascular necrosis of the femoral head. Which of the following treatments is most appropriate for early-stage avascular necrosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Core decompression

 

Option B)

 

  • Core decompression is done to decrease intraosseous pressure in femoral head.
  • The normal intraosseous pressure is 10-20 mm Hg. It is 3-4 times more in AVN.
  • It is the most appropriate procedure for early-stage AVN (stages 1 and 2).
  • The procedure involves drilling a small hole into the femoral head to relieve intraosseous pressure, improve blood flow, and promote healing.
  • By creating channels for blood supply, it can stimulate the regeneration of the bone and prevent further necrosis or collapse of the femoral head.
  • It is also supplemented with bone grafting (vascular or non-vascular) or electrical stimulation or Bone Morphogenic Proteins.
  • Core decompression has been shown to improve symptoms and delay the progression of AVN in many patients, making it a first-line treatment in the early stages.

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Total Hip Arthroplasty: It is typically indicated for advanced stages of AVN (stage 3 or 4) where the femoral head has collapsed, resulting in significant pain and dysfunction. It involves replacing the damaged hip joint with a prosthetic implant. It is a definitive treatment but not appropriate for early-stage AVN since preserving the native joint is preferable when possible.

 

 

 

Option C) Physiotherapy: Physiotherapy may play a role in rehabilitation but does not address the underlying problem of AVN. While physiotherapy can help maintain joint function and mobility, it won’t prevent disease progression in cases of AVN and is typically used as adjunctive therapy rather than a primary treatment.

 

Option D) Osteotomy: It is a surgical procedure used to realign the hip joint in cases where AVN has led to joint misalignment or significant pain. This procedure shifts the weight-bearing load from the affected area of the femoral head to a healthier area, potentially delaying the progression of AVN. It is usually reserved for intermediate stages of AVN or specific cases with favorable anatomy; not the first-line treatment for early-stage AVN.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Core decompression is the most appropriate treatment at this stage because it aims to restore blood supply to the affected bone, alleviate pain, and prevent further deterioration of the femoral head.
  • Core decompression is a targeted, effective approach for managing early-stage avascular necrosis.

questions.text: What is the most common type of shoulder instability?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anterior instability

 

Option A)

 

  • Anterior shoulder instability is characterized by a tendency for the humeral head to dislocate or subluxate anteriorly out of the glenoid cavity.
  • Causes:
  • Often occurs due to trauma, such as falling on an outstretched arm or direct blows to the shoulder.
  • Can also result from repetitive overhead activities (common in athletes) that place stress on the shoulder.
  • Clinical Presentation:
  • Patients may report a sensation of "giving way", especially during activities that involve reaching or throwing.
  • Signs of previous dislocation (e.g., flattened deltoid contour) may be present.
  • Physical examination may reveal apprehension or pain when the arm is placed in a position that reproduces instability.
  • Anterior instability is the most common type of shoulder instability, particularly in young athletes and those with a history of shoulder dislocations.
  • Management:
  • Initial treatment often involves physical therapy to strengthen the rotator cuff and stabilize the shoulder.
  • In cases of recurrent dislocations or significant functional impairment, surgical options (e.g., Bankart repair) may be indicated to restore stability.

 

Other options:

 

Option B) Posterior Instability: Posterior instability occurs when the humeral head dislocates or is prone to dislocate posteriorly out of the glenoid cavity. It is less common than anterior instability. It can result from trauma (e.g., seizures, electric shock) or repetitive shoulder motions that lead to fatigue and structural changes. It is often associated with a posterior dislocation of the shoulder. Patients may complain of shoulder pain, particularly during internal rotation or with activities that involve pushing. Physical examination may reveal weakness in the posterior shoulder and apprehension when the arm is placed in certain positions. Treatment usually starts with physical therapy focusing on strengthening the posterior shoulder muscles. Surgery may be considered in persistent cases, especially if there is significant structural damage.

 

Option C) Multidirectional Instability: Multidirectional instability (MDI) is characterized by a general laxity of the shoulder joint, leading to instability in multiple directions (anterior, posterior, and inferior). It is often associated with generalized joint hypermobility or can be secondary to repetitive overhead activities. It can be congenital or acquired through trauma or chronic overuse. Patients typically exhibit symptoms in multiple directions and may report a sensation of instability regardless of arm position. History often includes dislocations in various directions, and physical exam may show excessive motion in multiple planes. Initial treatment often involves physical therapy focusing on stabilization through strengthening and proprioceptive training. Surgical intervention is less common and usually reserved for cases that do not respond to conservative treatment.

 

Option D) Inferior Instability: Inferior instability refers to the shoulder's propensity to dislocate or subluxate inferiorly, which is quite rare. It may occur in cases of severe ligamentous laxity or following traumatic injuries. It is typically associated with extreme positions of the shoulder, such as overhead sports. Patients might experience pain and instability when the arm is held in elevated positions. Physical examination often reveals apprehension with abduction and external rotation. Treatment usually starts with physical therapy aimed at strengthening the stabilizing muscles around the shoulder. Surgery is rarely needed unless there is significant instability or structural damage.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Anterior instability is the most common type of shoulder instability, particularly among younger individuals and athletes, due to its prevalence in traumatic injuries and dislocations.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with a 2-year history of progressive knee pain and stiffness. She has a valgus deformity of the knee. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rheumatoid arthritis

 

Option B)

 

  • Rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic inflammatory autoimmune disorder that primarily affects joints but can also impact other systems.
  • Exact etiology is unknown; involves genetic factors and environmental triggers (e.g., infections).
  • Clinical Presentation:
  • Symmetrical joint involvement (both knees, hands, etc.).
  • Early morning stiffness lasting > 30 minutes, improving with activity.
  • Progressive pain, swelling, and stiffness in joints; may lead to deformities.
  • Valgus deformity can occur due to joint erosion and structural changes.

 

 

  • Systemic symptoms such as fatigue, weight loss, and fever may also be present.
  • Specific serological markers that are positive includes Rheumatoid factor (RF) and anti-citrullinated protein antibodies (anti-CCP).

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Osteoarthritis: It is a degenerative joint disease characterized by the breakdown of cartilage, leading to joint pain, stiffness, and functional limitations. Causes include age-related wear and tear, obesity, previous injuries, repetitive stress on the joint, and genetic predisposition. Clinical Presentation includes gradual onset of pain that worsens with activity and improves with rest, stiffness in the morning or after prolonged inactivity, typically lasting for <30 minutes, joint crepitus, tenderness, and swelling. Radiographic findings include joint space narrowing, osteophyte formation, and subchondral sclerosis.

 

 

While OA can lead to deformities, it usually results in varus (bow-legged) deformities in the knee, especially in the medial compartment.

 

 

 

Option C) Psoriatic Arthritis: It is a type of inflammatory arthritis associated with psoriasis, characterized by skin lesions. Autoimmune component with genetic predisposition; associated with psoriatic skin disease is the main cause. Clinical Presentation includes asymmetric joint pain and stiffness, dactylitis (sausage-like fingers/toes), nail changes like pitting and onycholysis may be present. It can affect any joint, but the presentation can vary widely. It is less commonly associated with deformities like knee valgus compared to RA, but it can still occur.

 

Option D) Gouty Arthritis: It is a type of inflammatory arthritis caused by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals in the joints due to hyperuricemia. The causes include genetic predisposition, dietary factors (high purine intake), renal insufficiency, and certain medications. Clinical Presentation includes sudden onset of intense joint pain, often starting at night, commonly affecting the big toe, redness, swelling, and tenderness in the affected joint. It is typically, not associated with chronic knee pain and progressive stiffness over years. It is not characterized by a valgus deformity of the knee.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • RA typically presents with symmetric joint involvement, prolonged morning stiffness, and can lead to joint deformities, including valgus deformity of the knee.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with a wrist injury after a fall. X-rays reveal a Salter-Harris type II fracture of the distal radius. What is the primary concern with this type of fracture?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Growth plate disturbance

 

Option A)

 

  • In Salter-Harris Type II fractures, the fracture line extends from physis into the metaphysis.
  • This gives a characteristic Thurston-Holland’s fragment sign on radiograph.

 

 

 

  • The primary concern with Salter-Harris type II fractures is potential disturbance of the growth plate, which can lead to complications in bone growth.
  • Damage to the growth plate can affect the normal proliferation of chondrocytes, leading to asymmetrical growth of the bone.
  • This can result in limb length discrepancies, angular deformities, or premature closure of the growth plate.
  • Given that the child is 12 years old, proper healing and monitoring of the fracture are essential to ensure normal growth and development.
  • If there is any misalignment or improper healing, it can have long-term implications for the child’s skeletal development.

 

Other options:

 

Option B) Malunion: Malunion refers to the healing of a fracture in a misaligned position, which can lead to functional impairment and deformity. While malunion is a concern with any fracture, it is particularly relevant if the fracture is not properly immobilized or if there is inadequate follow-up. Malunion can often be managed or corrected surgically, but the concern with Salter-Harris fractures is more directed towards the potential impact on growth plates than malunion itself, making this a secondary concern.

 

Option C) Infection: Infection is a potential complication of open fractures or those treated with surgical intervention. However, it is less of a concern with closed fractures like the typical Salter-Harris type II. Unless there are associated soft tissue injuries or if the fracture was open, the risk of infection is generally low. In this case, since the fracture was sustained from a fall and is likely closed, infection is not the primary concern.

 

Option D) Non-union: Non-union occurs when a fracture fails to heal properly, leading to persistent pain and functional impairment. Non-union is more common in certain types of fractures or in patients with underlying conditions affecting healing (e.g., metabolic disorders, nutritional deficiencies). Salter-Harris type II fractures usually have a favourable healing prognosis, so while non-union can be a concern, it is not the primary worry associated with this fracture type.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • This type of fracture has the potential to impact the growth and development of the bone, leading to long-term consequences if not properly managed.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents with a 6-month history of shoulder pain and weakness. She has a positive drop arm test. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rotator cuff tear

 

Option A)

 

  • A rotator cuff tear involves damage to one or more of the four muscles and their tendons that stabilize the shoulder joint: supraspinatus, infraspinatus, teres minor, and subscapularis.
  • Commonly occurs due to degenerative changes with age, overuse, or trauma.
  • Risk factors include age, repetitive overhead activities, and previous shoulder injuries.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Pain often localized to the lateral aspect of the shoulder and may radiate down the arm.
    • Weakness, particularly in overhead activities or lifting.
    • Drop Arm Test: A positive result indicates that the patient cannot maintain arm abduction against gravity, suggesting significant impairment of the supraspinatus muscle, often associated with a full-thickness tear.

 

 

  • The diagnosis is confirmed through physical examination, imaging studies (MRI or ultrasound), and specific functional tests.

 

 

 

  • Conservative treatment (physical therapy, analgesics) is ideal for partial tears; surgical intervention (arthroscopic repair) is required for full-thickness tears.

 

Other options:

 

Option B) Adhesive Capsulitis: Adhesive capsulitis is characterized by stiffness and pain in the shoulder joint, resulting from inflammation and thickening of the shoulder capsule. Exact cause is unknown, but risk factors include diabetes, prolonged immobility, and certain inflammatory conditions. Pain is typically severe, especially at night and with movement. Stiffness and progressive loss of range of motion in all planes (especially abduction and external rotation). Drop Arm Test is usually negative; patients may have limitations but can often hold the arm at various angles. Diagnosis is made on the basis of history and physical examination, supported by imaging (though X-rays are often normal). Physical therapy, corticosteroid injections, and in some cases, surgical capsular release are the treatment options.

 

Option C) Glenohumeral Osteoarthritis: Osteoarthritis of the glenohumeral joint involves degenerative changes in the joint cartilage, leading to pain, stiffness, and reduced function. Commonly seen in older adults and can be due to wear and tear, previous injuries, or inflammatory diseases. Pain typically worsens with activity and relieved by rest. Stiffness is present especially after periods of inactivity; limited range of motion, but more related to pain rather than a complete inability to move. Drop Arm Test may be positive due to pain, but weakness is not primarily due to a rotator cuff problem. Diagnosis is made based on clinical findings and confirmed by radiographic evidence of joint space narrowing, osteophytes, and subchondral sclerosis.

 

 

 

Conservative treatments include physical therapy, medications, and corticosteroid injections; surgical options may include arthroplasty for severe cases.

 

Option D) Scapular Winging: Scapular winging occurs when the scapula protrudes posteriorly away from the thoracic wall, often due to weakness or paralysis of the serratus anterior muscle. It is commonly caused by long thoracic nerve injury, muscular dystrophies, or trauma. Visual deformity of the scapula when pushing against a wall or raising the arms is seen. Patient may not have significant pain unless associated with another condition.

 

 

 

Drop Arm Test is not relevant to scapular winging, as it primarily assesses rotator cuff function rather than scapular stability. Diagnosis is made based on physical examination, strength testing, and neurological evaluation. Management focusses on strengthening exercises and addressing underlying nerve issues; surgery may be necessary in persistent cases.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The positive drop arm test specifically suggests significant impairment in the supraspinatus muscle, which is typically involved in full-thickness rotator cuff tears.

choices.text: Open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF)

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with a 2-day history of severe ankle pain and swelling after a sports injury. The X-ray shows a fracture of the lateral malleolus. What is the most important step in the initial management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Immobilization in a cast

 

Option C)

 

  • Isolated non-displaced lateral malleolar fractures have a low risk of complications and have good clinical results regardless of treatment. 
  • Small non-displaced avulsion fractures of the tip of the lateral malleolus are best treated with early mobilization similar to an ankle sprain.
  • A functional splint can be given during the healing process.
  • Ankle rehabilitation exercises can be started as soon as symptoms allow.
  • Isolated oblique lateral malleolar fractures at or below the level of the ankle joint should be immobilized in a walking fracture boot or short-leg walking cast for 4-6 weeks.
  • Care should be taken to immobilize the ankle in a neutral position (90 flexion) to minimize Achilles tendon shortening.
  • The patient should be seen in 10-14 days to check the condition of the cast or and to ensure that alignment remains acceptable.
  • At 4 weeks, if the fracture site is non-tender and the repeat radiographs show evidence of fracture union, the patient may begin gradual weight bearing and ankle rehabilitation.
  • If no radiographic evidence of healing is apparent, the patient should remain immobilized for an additional 2 weeks and then repeat the radiograph.
  • If the patient is still not clinically healed (non-tender over the fracture site and some callus evident on the radiograph) at 6 weeks, a removable fracture boot should be used and daily range of motion exercises started to minimize the stiffness and disuse muscle atrophy that can be caused by further immobilization.
  • Radiographs are repeated and the patient is re-examined at 8 weeks.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Closed Reduction: It involves realigning the fractured bones without making an incision. It is typically used for fractures with significant displacement. Closed reduction may be necessary if the fracture is displaced and needs to be aligned properly for healing. However, this is often followed by immobilization rather than being the first step in all cases. Additionally, closed reduction can be painful and may not be appropriate if there are complications like severe swelling or vascular compromise.

 

Option B) Open Reduction and Internal Fixation (ORIF): This involves surgical fixation of the fracture via exposure through incision, and stabilizing it with hardware (plates, screws). This is generally reserved for unstable fractures, especially those with significant displacement, or when closed reduction is unsuccessful. ORIF is a more invasive approach and involves risks such as infection, longer recovery time, and complications associated with surgery. It is not usually the first step in management unless there are specific indications (e.g., unstable fracture or malalignment).

 

Option D) Pain Management with Analgesics: Pain management is an essential aspect of fracture care. While controlling pain is critical and should be a component of treatment, it does not address the need for stabilization and healing of the fracture itself. Thus, while it is important, it is not the most important initial management step compared to immobilization.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Immobilization in a cast stabilizes the fracture, prevents further displacement, and allows for the natural healing process to begin.
  • Appropriate management begins with ensuring the stability of the fracture through immobilization, making it the priority in initial care.

choices.text: Lateral curvature of the spine
Lateral curvature with rotation of spine
Flexion deformity of the spine

questions.text: Idiopathic scoliosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lateral curvature with rotation of spine

 

Option C)

 

  • This option accurately describes idiopathic scoliosis, which involves both a lateral curvature and a rotational deformity of the vertebrae.
  • In idiopathic scoliosis, as the spine curves laterally, the vertebrae also rotate toward the concavity of the curve.
  • This combination can lead to changes in posture, rib deformities, and potential impact on lung and heart function in severe cases.
  • Therefore, this option is the most comprehensive and correct description.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Lateral curvature of the spine: This option describes a basic characteristic of scoliosis, which is the presence of a lateral curvature of the spine. While lateral curvature is indeed a hallmark of scoliosis, it does not capture the full complexity of idiopathic scoliosis, which also involves rotation of the spine.

 

Option B) Rotation of the spine: Although idiopathic scoliosis does involve rotation, this option alone is incomplete. Scoliosis typically involves both curvature and rotation, so it cannot stand alone as a definition.

 

Option D) Flexion deformity of the spine: This is not characteristic of scoliosis. While certain postural abnormalities can result in a flexed spine, idiopathic scoliosis specifically refers to a lateral curvature and rotation, not a forward bending. This option does not accurately represent the condition.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Lateral curvature with rotation of the spine fully encompasses the dual nature of the deformity seen in idiopathic scoliosis.

choices.text: Open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF)

questions.text: A 20-year-old athlete presents with a 2-day history of severe knee pain and swelling after a sports injury. The X-ray shows a fracture of the patella. What is the most important step in the initial management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF)

 

Option B)

 

  • ORIF expose the fracture site, realign the fragments, and stabilize them with hardware like screws or plates.
  • It is recommended for displaced fractures, particularly those involving the joint surface, as it provides optimal alignment and stability.
  • In athletes, maintaining proper knee function and preventing complications (like post-traumatic arthritis) is crucial.
  • ORIF allows for better restoration of anatomy, potentially leading to quicker recovery and return to sports.
  • Given the patient's age and activity level, this is often the preferred approach for a patellar fracture.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Closed Reduction: It is suitable for non-displaced fractures or those where alignment can be achieved without surgery. In the case of a patellar fracture, if the fragments are displaced or if the fracture involves the joint surface, closed reduction may not provide adequate stability or alignment. This method also carries a risk of malunion or non-union if the fracture is unstable.

 

Option C) Immobilization in a Cast: It is generally appropriate for stable, non-displaced fractures. While casting can help in some cases, it may not provide adequate stability for displaced fractures. Furthermore, immobilization can lead to stiffness and decreased range of motion, particularly in an athlete who requires functional knee movement. Therefore, in the case of a displaced patellar fracture, casting alone is insufficient.

 

Option D) Pain Management with Analgesics: It is essential for all patients to manage acute pain associated with injury. While pain management is important and should be part of the overall management strategy, it does not address the underlying issue of the fracture itself. Without addressing the fracture (especially if displaced), pain management alone is not adequate.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) ensures proper alignment, stabilization, and optimal recovery for the athlete, allowing for a quicker return to sports.

choices.text: Carpal tunnel syndrome
De Quervain's tenosynovitis

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a 1-year history of progressive wrist pain and stiffness. She has a history of repetitive strain injury. Finkelstein test is positive. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) De Quervain's tenosynovitis

 

Option B)

 

  • It is the inflammation of the tendons and synovial sheath of the abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis, located at the radial side of the wrist.
  • Patients experience pain along the radial side of the wrist and base of the thumb, often exacerbated by thumb movement or gripping.
  • There may be swelling, and a positive Finkelstein test (pain on ulnar deviation while the thumb is held in a fist) is typically noted.

 

 

 

  • Given the history of repetitive strain injury, this diagnosis is highly likely.
  • The progressive nature of the pain and stiffness aligns well with de Quervain's tenosynovitis, especially as it can result from repetitive thumb and wrist motions, common in many activities.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Carpal Tunnel Syndrome: It is a condition caused by compression of the median nerve as it passes through the carpal tunnel in the wrist. Symptoms are characterized by pain, numbness, tingling, and weakness in the thumb, index, and middle fingers. Symptoms often worsen at night or with repetitive wrist movements. While carpal tunnel syndrome can arise from repetitive strain and may cause wrist pain, it typically presents with specific sensory symptoms and affects the fingers more than the wrist joint itself. The stiffness is not a prominent feature, making this option less likely.

 

Option C) Scaphoid Fracture: A fracture of the scaphoid bone in the wrist, often results from a fall onto an outstretched hand. It typically presents with pain in the anatomical snuffbox and wrist, swelling, and decreased range of motion. X-rays may not always show the fracture initially. A scaphoid fracture usually has a more acute onset following an injury. In this case, the patient has a 1-year history of progressive symptoms without a specific traumatic event noted, making this option less likely.

 

Option D) Wrist Sprain: An injury to the ligaments in the wrist, often caused by sudden twisting or impact is the wrist sprain. Symptoms include pain, swelling, and limited range of motion in the wrist. Pain may be localized to the affected ligament(s). Wrist sprains typically arise from a specific incident or trauma. While repetitive strain could theoretically lead to chronic instability or sprain-like symptoms, the term "sprain" implies an acute mechanism rather than a year-long progression of pain and stiffness.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The progressive nature of wrist pain and stiffness, coupled with the history of repetitive strain injury, strongly aligns with this condition.
  • It directly involves the tendons affected by repetitive wrist and thumb movements, making it the most appropriate diagnosis.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl presented in emergency department with elbow pain, swelling in the hand and elbow as well. She unable to move her elbow as it aggravates her pain and swelling. Her pulse was also feeble. An X-Ray was performed as given below. Identify the vessel probably ruptured.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Brachial artery

 

Option B)

 

  • The brachial artery is a major blood vessel in the arm, running down the medial side of the humerus and bifurcating into the radial and ulnar arteries at the elbow.
  • This artery is directly associated with the elbow and is at risk of injury in supracondylar fractures or severe elbow dislocations.
  • If the brachial artery is compromised, it could lead to significant swelling, pain, and decreased perfusion to the forearm and hand, resulting in a feeble pulse.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Ulnar Artery: The ulnar artery is one of the two major arteries supplying the forearm, primarily along the ulnar side. It branches off the brachial artery at the cubital fossa and runs down the forearm to the wrist. Rupture of the ulnar artery typically affects the wrist and hand, not primarily the elbow. Symptoms would include pain and swelling in the ulnar distribution, but it would be less likely to cause significant changes in the pulse at the elbow.

 

Option C) Axillary Artery: The axillary artery is located in the upper arm and supplies blood to the shoulder and upper limb. It transitions into the brachial artery at the lower border of the teres major muscle. Injury to the axillary artery typically occurs with shoulder dislocations or fractures of the proximal humerus. While it can lead to significant vascular issues, it would not usually present with elbow pain and swelling as described.

 

Option D) Radial Artery: The radial artery runs along the radial side of the forearm, branching from the brachial artery at the elbow. Injury to the radial artery can lead to localized symptoms in the forearm and hand, primarily affecting the thumb and lateral side of the wrist. While a rupture can cause swelling and pain, it is less likely to be the primary issue when the symptoms are centered on the elbow.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The given image shows the supracondylar humerus fracture.
  • The most commonly injured vessel in this fracture is the brachial artery.
  • Brachial artery is the most probable cause of patient’s pain, swelling, and feeble pulse in this case, especially in the context of potential trauma.
  • The other arteries are either not directly involved or less likely to cause the specific symptoms presented.

questions.text: All the following are causes of avascular necrosis of the femoral head except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Unmatched Blood Transfusion

 

Option D)

 

  • Unmatched blood transfusions can lead to hemolytic reactions and a variety of complications.
  • However, they are not directly associated with the mechanisms that lead to avascular necrosis.
  • The primary risks associated with unmatched blood transfusions include acute hemolytic reactions, allergic reactions, and transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI), but these do not typically result in avascular necrosis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Alcoholism: Chronic alcohol consumption can lead to fatty changes in the blood and the formation of lipid deposits in small blood vessels. This can impair blood flow and cause vascular occlusion, resulting in reduced blood supply to the femoral head. Studies show that alcoholism is associated with an increased incidence of avascular necrosis, particularly in the femoral head, as it can lead to both direct effects on the bone and indirect effects by causing liver dysfunction and metabolic disturbances.

 

Option B) Steroid Therapy: Corticosteroids can cause AVN through several pathways, including direct toxicity to osteoblasts and osteocytes, increased intraosseous pressure due to fat cell hypertrophy, and disruption of the microvascular supply to the bone. Long-term use of high-dose corticosteroids is a recognized risk factor for avascular necrosis, especially in conditions requiring prolonged steroid therapy, such as autoimmune diseases.

 

Option C) Patient on Renal Dialysis: Patients on renal dialysis may experience multiple complications, including mineral and bone disorders, which can lead to bone necrosis. Dialysis itself can alter the metabolism of bone minerals and affect blood flow. While renal failure and dialysis are associated with bone disorders, including secondary hyperparathyroidism and osteodystrophy, they are not direct causes of avascular necrosis in the femoral head.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Unmatched blood transfusion does not relate to the mechanisms that lead to avascular necrosis of the femoral head.
  • In contrast, options A, B, and C all represent known risk factors for AVN, with A and B being well-established causes, while C relates to general bone health rather than directly causing AVN.

questions.text: What is the name of the procedure where a tendon is transferred from one location to another to restore function?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tendon transfer

 

Option B)

 

  • Tendon transfer is a surgical procedure in which a tendon is relocated from its original position to another site to restore function, often compensating for a lost or weakened muscle.
  • This procedure is indicated in cases of muscle weakness, paralysis, or deformity.
  • Common applications include restoring wrist function in individuals with brachial plexus injuries or correcting toe deformities.
  • The tendon is detached from its original attachment site and reattached to a new location, often where it can restore function to an impaired area.
  • Care is taken to ensure that the new tendon position allows for optimal muscle function.
  • This option directly addresses the question, as tendon transfer specifically involves relocating a tendon to improve function.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Tendon Repair: Tendon repair is a surgical procedure aimed at reattaching or suturing a torn or damaged tendon back to its original position. This procedure is typically performed when a tendon is completely ruptured, often due to acute injury, and aims to restore the tendon’s integrity and function. The surgeon cleans the area, aligns the tendon ends, and sutures them together, sometimes using specialized techniques or anchors to provide stability. While tendon repair is essential for restoring function after a tear, it does not involve moving the tendon to a new location. Thus, it does not meet the criteria specified in the question.

 

Option C) Tendon Grafting: Tendon grafting involves using a donor tendon (from the patient or a cadaver) to replace a damaged or lost tendon. This procedure is used when a tendon is irreparably damaged or absent, often in cases of extensive injuries or congenital defects. The surgeon harvests a tendon from another part of the body (autograft) or uses a donor tendon (allograft). The graft is then attached at both ends to restore function to the affected area. Tendon grafting does not involve relocating an existing tendon; rather, it provides a new tendon to replace one that is absent or severely injured. Thus, it does not fit the question’s criteria.

 

Option D) Tendon Augmentation: Tendon augmentation is a procedure in which a tendon is reinforced or strengthened, often using additional material (like a graft) to improve its function or repair a defect. This technique is often employed in cases of chronic tendinopathy or when the existing tendon is weak but not completely torn. The surgeon may add a graft to the existing tendon to provide support and improve function, typically in combination with other procedures. While tendon augmentation aims to enhance tendon function, it does not involve relocating the tendon to a new site. Therefore, it does not meet the criteria specified in the question.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Tendon transfer involves relocating a tendon from one site to another to restore function, making it the most suitable choice based on the question’s requirements.

questions.text: The child with the following clinical presentation will most probably have the underlying diagnosis of:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Muscular Dystrophy

 

Option A)

 

  • Muscular Dystrophy refers to a group of disorders characterized by the progressive degeneration of muscle tissue, leading to weakness and loss of function.
  • The most common form is Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD).
  • In children, symptoms can include muscle weakness, difficulty in motor skills (like running or climbing stairs), pseudohypertrophy of the calves, and eventual loss of ambulation.
  • Often, affected children show delayed developmental milestones and may have difficulty maintaining posture.
  • If the clinical presentation indicates muscle weakness, delayed development, and potentially a family history of similar symptoms, dystrophy is a likely diagnosis.
  • Given the context of this question, if the child exhibits signs of muscle degeneration or weakness, dystrophy would be the most probable underlying diagnosis.

 

Other options:

 

Option B) Neuropathy: Neuropathy refers to damage or disease affecting peripheral nerves, which can lead to a variety of symptoms, including weakness, numbness, and pain. In children, symptoms can include weakness in certain muscle groups, sensory deficits, or diminished reflexes. Depending on the type of neuropathy (e.g., hereditary, traumatic, or acquired), the clinical presentation can vary widely. While neuropathy could explain some motor symptoms, it often presents with additional sensory changes and is less likely to be diagnosed as dystrophy if the primary issue is muscle weakness without sensory involvement.

 

Option C) Metaphyseal Dysplasia: Metaphyseal dysplasia refers to a group of conditions that affect the metaphysis and can lead to bone deformities. Symptoms may include skeletal abnormalities, pain, and possible functional limitations. Common examples include disorders like Metaphyseal Chondrodysplasia, which can present with bowing of the legs or shortened stature.

 

 

 

If the child has skeletal deformities or growth abnormalities, this might be a consideration, but it usually does not directly cause muscle weakness. Therefore, unless there are specific skeletal findings, it is less likely the primary diagnosis if muscle weakness is the main issue.

 

Option D) Neurofibromatosis (NF): Neurofibromatosis is a genetic disorder that causes tumours to grow on nerves. The most common forms are NF1 and NF2. In children, NF1 often presents with café-au-lait spots, neurofibromas, and possible learning disabilities.

 

 

 

Café-au-lait spots and neurofibromas

 

NF2 is characterized by bilateral vestibular schwannomas and may lead to hearing loss.

 

 

 

Bilateral vestibular schwannomas

 

While NF can lead to neurological symptoms, it generally presents with specific skin findings and tumours rather than primarily causing muscle weakness. If muscle weakness is a major concern, NF is unlikely to be the diagnosis unless there are significant nerve-related symptoms.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Muscular Dystrophy typically presents with muscle degeneration, which aligns closely with the symptoms of calf muscle pseudohypertrophy described in the question.

choices.text: Posterior medial soft tissue release

questions.text: A mother came to the OPD with her 2-year-old baby with deformity of the feet as shown in the image. What is most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Manipulation & Cast

 

Option A)

 

  • Manipulation and cast application is a common initial treatment for clubfoot or congenital talipes equinovarus (CTEV).
  • The Ponseti method involves a series of gentle manipulations to correct the deformity, followed by the application of a cast to maintain the corrected position.
  • This process is usually repeated weekly for several weeks.
  • This approach is most effective when started early, ideally within the first few weeks of life but still applicable in toddlers.
  • It aims to correct the foot's position without surgical intervention initially.
  • Advantages: Minimally invasive, non-surgical approach, and can achieve good correction when done properly.

 

Other options:

 

Option B) Posterior Medial Soft Tissue Release: This is a surgical procedure that involves releasing tight soft tissues on the posterior and medial aspects of the foot and ankle to correct deformities, typically performed if conservative management fails. This procedure is usually indicated for more severe or resistant cases of clubfoot or when conservative measures have not adequately corrected the deformity. It can provide significant correction for rigid deformities but is more invasive and has a longer recovery time. This option is typically not the first choice for a child as young as 2 unless previous treatments have been unsuccessful.

 

Option C) Triple Arthrodesis: This is a surgical procedure that fuses the three main joints of the foot (subtalar, talonavicular, and calcaneocuboid joints) to correct severe deformities and provide stability. It is generally reserved for older children or adults, particularly when there is significant arthritic change or failed previous corrective surgeries. It can provide a stable foot for weight-bearing activities. It is not appropriate for a 2-year-old as a first-line treatment, especially for flexible deformities like clubfoot.

 

Option D) Evans Procedure: This surgical technique is performed to correct flatfoot deformities, involving lateral column lengthening and realignment of the foot. It is not commonly indicated for clubfoot and is more suitable for cases of flexible flatfoot in older children or adults. It can help improve the structure and function of the foot in appropriate cases. It is not relevant for a 2-year-old with typical foot deformities like clubfoot.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • For a 2-year-old child with a deformity of the feet, if the condition is clubfoot, the initial treatment of choice is manipulation followed by casting.
  • It is non-invasive and effective when initiated early.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with a 1-year history of progressive hip pain and stiffness. He has a history of hip replacement surgery 10 years ago and a positive hip aspiration. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Infection

 

Option B)

 

  • Infection in a joint prosthesis, known as periprosthetic joint infection (PJI), can occur due to bacteria entering the joint during surgery or from hematogenous spread from other sites.
  • Symptoms:
  • Progressive pain and stiffness, often accompanied by swelling, warmth, or fever.
  • Patients may report pain that is worse at night or with activity.
  • Positive hip aspiration indicates the presence of purulent material or positive cultures.
  • Joint aspiration (arthrocentesis) typically reveals elevated white blood cell counts and may yield positive cultures for bacteria.
  • Imaging may show soft tissue swelling or other signs of infection.

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Aseptic Loosening: Aseptic loosening occurs when the implant becomes unstable due to the failure of the bond between the bone and the prosthetic material without the presence of infection. Symptoms include gradual onset of pain, often worsening with activity, stiffness and reduced range of motion in the hip. Causes are wear and tear of the implant, bone resorption around the implant (osteolysis) due to wear debris. Radiographic findings may show radiolucent lines around the implant. No signs of infection on aspiration or culture.

 

 

Option C) Heterotopic Ossification: Heterotopic ossification (HO) refers to the abnormal formation of bone in soft tissues around a joint, often following surgery or trauma. Symptoms include pain and stiffness in the affected joint, limited range of motion as the condition progresses. Commonly seen after hip surgery, especially in certain populations (e.g., traumatic injuries, neurological conditions). X-rays may reveal calcified masses in soft tissues adjacent to the joint. Aspiration typically would not yield an infectious process; thus, cultures would be negative.

 

 

Option D) Periprosthetic Fracture: A periprosthetic fracture occurs when there is a fracture of the bone surrounding a prosthetic implant, which can happen due to trauma or stress on the bone. Sudden onset of pain after a fall or injury. Symptoms may include localized swelling and inability to bear weight on the affected leg. X-rays would typically show a fracture line near the prosthesis. Aspiration would not typically reveal infection unless there is associated osteomyelitis.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The presence of progressive hip pain, stiffness, and a positive aspiration strongly indicates a periprosthetic joint infection, which requires prompt diagnosis and management.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents with knee pain after a basketball game. She reports feeling a "pop" in her knee, and it is now swollen and unstable. Lachmann test was positive. What is the most likely injury?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) tear

 

Option C)

 

  • The ACL is a key ligament that stabilizes the knee by preventing forward movement of the tibia relative to the femur.
  • Tears often occur in sports involving jumping, pivoting, or rapid deceleration.
  • A sudden "pop" sound is heard or felt at the time of injury.
  • There may be an immediate swelling due to bleeding in the joint (hemarthrosis).
  • Instability or a feeling of the knee "giving way," particularly with weight-bearing activities is a characteristic complaint.
  • ACL injuries commonly occur during sports when the knee is slightly flexed and a forceful twist or change in direction is applied.
  • Physical examination can show a positive Lachman test or anterior drawer test.

 

 

 

  • MRI is used to confirm the diagnosis and assess the extent of injury.

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Meniscus Tear: The menisci are C-shaped cartilages located between the femur and tibia that act as shock absorbers and stabilize the knee. Tears often occur due to twisting motions, especially while bearing weight. Pain, especially along the joint line, swelling and stiffness in the knee, feeling of catching or locking, as fragments may get stuck in the joint are the symptoms of a meniscus tear. Instability may occur, but it’s not the primary symptom. A meniscus tear can happen when the knee is flexed and twisted, common in sports involving quick changes in direction. Physical examination may reveal tenderness along the joint line and positive special tests (e.g., McMurray's test).

 

 

MRI is often used to confirm the diagnosis.

 

 

Option B) Patellar Dislocation: Patellar dislocation occurs when the patella slips out of its normal position, usually laterally. This injury is common in sports. Symptoms include sudden pain and swelling in the knee, visible deformity or an inability to move the knee normally, a feeling of instability or the knee giving way, especially when trying to change direction or load the knee. This injury typically results from a direct blow or an awkward landing from a jump, causing the patella to dislocate. A physical examination may show an unstable patella and swelling. X-rays can confirm the dislocation.

 

 

Option D) Lateral Collateral Ligament (LCL) Tear: The LCL is located on the outer side of the knee and provides stability against varus stress. Symptoms include pain on the outer side of the knee. Swelling may occur, but it is usually less pronounced than with ACL injuries. Instability can happen, particularly when the knee is stressed laterally. LCL injuries typically result from a direct blow to the inside of the knee, causing excessive stress on the outer side. Physical examination may reveal tenderness over the LCL and laxity with varus stress testing. MRI can help visualize the injury.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The acute nature of the injury, the audible "pop," and the resulting instability are classic signs of an ACL tear, particularly in athletes.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with hip pain and an inability to bear weight after a fall. X-rays show a displaced femoral neck fracture. What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Surgical fixation

 

Option B)

 

  • Surgical fixation involves surgical intervention to stabilize the fracture.
  • Options may include internal fixation with screws, a sliding hip screw, or hip arthroplasty (partial or total) depending on factors like patient age, activity level, and bone quality.
  • Displaced femoral neck fractures typically require surgical intervention to restore anatomy, stabilize the fracture, and enable early mobilization.
  • Surgical fixation reduces the risk of complications associated with displacement, including avascular necrosis and nonunion.
  • Advantages:
  • Allows for early weight bearing and rehabilitation.
  • Generally, leads to better functional outcomes compared to non-surgical management.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Non-weight bearing with crutches: Non-weight bearing (NWB) with crutches means the patient would be instructed not to put any weight on the affected leg, using crutches for mobility. This approach may be appropriate for certain non-displaced fractures or in specific patients where surgery is not an option due to comorbidities. In the case of a displaced femoral neck fracture, this option is inadequate because it does not address the instability and potential complications of displacement, such as avascular necrosis of the femoral head or nonunion. Prolonged NWB can lead to muscle atrophy, joint stiffness, and decreased mobility.

 

Option C) Physical therapy: Physical therapy involves exercises and modalities to improve strength, mobility, and function. Typically, physical therapy is essential for rehabilitation after a surgical procedure or in the recovery of certain musculoskeletal injuries. In the case of an acute displaced femoral neck fracture, physical therapy alone is not appropriate until the fracture is stabilized. Initiating therapy before addressing the fracture could lead to further injury or complications.

 

Option D) Analgesics and rest: This approach involves prescribing pain relief medication and advising the patient to rest. Analgesics can help manage pain in various orthopedic conditions. While analgesics may provide short-term relief, they do not address the underlying problem of the displaced fracture. Resting alone does not facilitate healing or restore function in the presence of a significant injury like a displaced femoral neck fracture.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Surgical fixation is the most appropriate initial management.
  • This option addresses the need for stability and promotes better long-term outcomes, allowing for early mobilization and rehabilitation, which are crucial in elderly patients.

questions.text: In a patient with gouty arthritis, strongly birefringent needle-shaped crystals with negative elongation in synovial fluid aspiration are composed of:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Monosodium Urate

 

  • Monosodium urate (MSU) crystals are derived from uric acid, which can precipitate in tissues and joints when serum uric acid levels are high (hyperuricemia).
  • In gout, the crystals are typically needle-shaped and exhibit strong birefringence with a negative elongation pattern (negative bifringent) when viewed under polarized light.
  • The presence of these crystals in synovial fluid is diagnostic for gouty arthritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Calcium Pyrophosphate: Calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate (CPPD) crystals are associated with another form of arthritis known as pseudogout. These crystals are typically rhomboid-shaped and exhibit weak birefringence with a positive elongation pattern under polarized light. (positive bifringent) The identification of these crystals is associated with pseudogout, not gouty arthritis.

 

Option C. Homogentisic Acid: Homogentisic acid is a metabolite associated with alkaptonuria, a rare metabolic disorder. It does not form characteristic crystals seen in gout or pseudogout; rather, it may lead to pigmentation and other joint issues but is not identified through synovial fluid analysis for gout. It is not relevant to gouty arthritis diagnostics.

 

Option D. Sodium Pyrophosphate: Incorrect form the relevant compound in pseudogout is calcium pyrophosphate, not sodium.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • In gouty arthritis, the classic finding on synovial fluid analysis is:
    • Needle-shaped crystals
    • Negatively birefringent under polarized light
    • Show yellow colour when aligned parallel to the slow axis (negative elongation)

 

  • These crystals are composed of monosodium urate.
  • Quick Crystal Comparison:

questions.text: A 53-year-old female presented with complaints of knee pain for past 6 months. She adds that pain is aggravated mostly whenever she sits after performing household work. On examination by orthopedic doctor, there was not only tenderness but also needle-shaped crystals with negative bifringence under microscopic examination of synovial fluids. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gout

 

Option A)

 

GOUT

 

  • It is a disorder of purine metabolism characterized by hyperuricemia, deposition of monosodium urate monohydrate crystals in joints and periarticular tissues, and recurrent attacks of acute synovitis.
  • Late changes include cartilage degeneration, renal dysfunction and uric acid urolithiasis.
  • It is commoner in men than in women (20:1).
  • The patients have serum urate concentration of 0.42 mmol/L (7 mg/dL) if male and 0.35 mmoL/L (5.8 mg/dL) if female – known as hyperuricemia.
  • The risk of developing clinical features of gout increases with increasing levels of serum uric acid, only a fraction of those with hyperuricemia develop symptoms.
  • Tophi are nodular deposits of monosodium urate monohydrate crystals, with an associated foreign body reaction.
  • It is deposited in minute clumps in connective tissues.

 

 

  • The commonest sites are metatarsophalangeal joint of big toe > ankle and finger joints and olecranon bursae.
  • The skin is red, shiny, swollen, hot and extremely tender suggesting a cellulitis or septic arthritis.

 

 

  • The pain on the affected site worsens with activity during the gout flares.
  • Characteristic negatively birefringent urate crystals in the synovial fluid examined by polarizing microscopy is diagnostic.
  • During acute gouty attack, strongly negatively birefringent needle-shaped mono sodium urate (MSU) crystals are seen (diagnostic).

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Pseudo gout. Pseudo gout is caused by calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate (CPPD) crystals. Rhomboid-shaped crystals with positive birefringent crystals are seen.

 

Option C. Ankylosing spondylitis. It is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy, a genetically determined generalized chronic inflammatory disease that primarily affects the axial skeleton (sacroiliac joint and spine) with variable involvement of root joints (shoulder and hip) and

peripheral joints. The involvement is an enthesopathy. Knee is not commonly involved in this condition and there is no crystal production seen here.

 

Option D. Osteoarthritis. It commonly affects the hands, knees, hip and spine. The knees are more commonly affected than the hip. There is a formation of loose bodies that can be seen on the x-rays.

 

Educational objective:

 

The negative bifringence is seen in gout, characteristic of needle-shaped crystals of monosodium urate monohydrate crystals.

choices.text: Fracture of the lateral malleolus

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with a painful swollen ankle after landing awkwardly during a soccer game. Physical examination reveals tenderness over the lateral malleolus and a positive anterior drawer test. What is the likely injury?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lateral ankle sprain

 

Option B)

 

  • A lateral ankle sprain occurs when the ligaments on the outer side of the ankle, commonly the anterior talofibular ligament and calcaneofibular ligament are stretched or torn.
  • Symptoms:
    • Pain and swelling around the lateral ankle.
    • Tenderness over the lateral malleolus.
    • Instability when bearing weight, especially during movement.
  • A positive anterior drawer test indicates instability of the ankle, commonly due to injury to the anterior talofibular ligament.
  • Clinical examination, including the anterior drawer test, is pivotal.
  • X-rays may be performed to rule out fractures, but they often show no acute findings in a sprain.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Fracture of the Lateral Malleolus: A fracture of the lateral malleolus involves a break in the fibula bone near the ankle. Symptoms includes severe pain around the lateral ankle, swelling and bruising, and difficulty bearing weight. X-rays are typically required to confirm a fracture. Examination may reveal tenderness specifically over the fracture site, and the anterior drawer test may not be positive.

 

 

Option C) Achilles Tendon Rupture: An Achilles tendon rupture involves a tear of the Achilles tendon, which connects the calf muscles to the heel. Symptoms include sudden sharp pain in the back of the ankle or calf, often described as feeling like a "kick" or "pop", swelling and bruising may occur, typically in the calf area, difficulty in plantarflexing the foot or standing on tiptoes. Physical examination may reveal a positive Thompson test (no plantarflexion when squeezing the calf). The location of tenderness and pain differs from that seen in ankle sprains.

 

 

 

Thompson Test

 

Option D) Syndesmotic Injury: A syndesmotic injury (high ankle sprain) involves damage to the syndesmosis, the fibrous joint between the fibula and tibia. Symptoms include pain above the ankle, particularly on the outer side, swelling around the ankle, and difficulty bearing weight, but more localized to the proximal fibula. The squeeze test (compression of the tibia and fibula) may be positive. X-rays may be required to confirm widening of the syndesmosis.

 

 

 

A. Squeeze Test; B. X-ray finding in syndesmotic injury

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Lateral ankle sprain injury is common in athletes and is characterized by instability due to ligament damage on the lateral side of the ankle.

choices.text: Splinting and follow-up in a week

questions.text: A 30-year-old male cyclist presents with wrist pain after a fall onto an outstretched hand. An X-ray shows a fracture of the scaphoid. What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Immobilization in a cast

 

Option A)

 

  • Scaphoid fractures are prone to non-union due to their poor blood supply.
  • Immobilizing the wrist in a cast helps to keep the bone fragments in place and promote healing.
  • The scaphoid fractures are immobilized in a glass-holding cast.

 

 

 

  • The cast is indicated in stable, non-displaced scaphoid fractures.
  • Unstable, displaced fractures are treated operatively by stabilizing the fracture through a screw.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B) Surgery: Surgical intervention may be indicated for displaced scaphoid fractures or those that show nonunion despite conservative treatment. Surgery (such as screw fixation) is often reserved for fractures that are significantly displaced or for patients who are high-risk for complications. Early surgical intervention might be warranted if there is concern for avascular necrosis or if conservative management fails.

 

Option C) Thumb spica cast: In terms of scaphoid fracture treatment, a thumb spica cast is often considered a viable option, but it's not always the most appropriate choice. It is less restrictive and allows movement of the fingers and forearm compared to a cast. It can be effective for mild to moderate fractures. Compared to a cast, a thumb spica cast may not provide much stability to the scaphoid bone, increasing the risk of non-union.

 

Option D) Splinting and Follow-up in a Week: This option involves using a splint to support the wrist without the rigidity of a cast, with plans to reassess in a week. Splinting may provide some initial support but does not offer the necessary immobilization required for a scaphoid fracture. There is a risk that inadequate immobilization can lead to nonunion or malunion of the fracture.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Immobilization in a cast provides the necessary immobilization to facilitate proper healing of the scaphoid bone, minimizing the risk of complications.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with chronic shoulder pain and limited range of motion. Physical examination reveals a positive Neer and Hawkins test. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Shoulder impingement syndrome

 

Option B)

 

  • Shoulder impingement syndrome occurs when the rotator cuff tendons become irritated and inflamed as they pass through the shoulder joint, particularly under the acromion.
  • Symptoms:
  • Pain during overhead activities.
  • Limited range of motion, particularly in abduction and internal rotation.
  • Positive Neer and Hawkins tests indicate impingement of the rotator cuff tendons.
  • Neer’s test:
  • The examiner stabilizes the patient's scapula with one hand, while passively flexing the arm with internally rotation.
  • If the patient reports pain in this position, then the result of the test is considered to be positive.

 

 

 

  • Hawkin’s test:
  • The examiner places the patient's arm in 90 shoulder flexion with the elbow flexed to 90 and then internally rotates the arm.
  • The test is considered to be positive if the patient experiences pain with internal rotation.

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Rotator Cuff Tear: A rotator cuff tear involves damage to one or more of the tendons of the rotator cuff muscles, which stabilize and allow for movement of the shoulder. Symptoms include pain, especially during overhead activities, weakness in arm elevation, limited range of motion, particularly in abduction and external rotation, and night pain and difficulty sleeping on the affected side. Physical examination may show weakness in specific muscle groups (supraspinatus, infraspinatus, etc.). Imaging, such as MRI or ultrasound, can confirm the tear. Various special tests done for rotator cuff tears are:

 

  • Subscapularis: Lift-Off Test, Belly Press Test, Bear Hug Test
  • Supraspinatus and Infraspinatus: External Rotation Lag Sign, Jobe’s Test, Drop Arm Test
  • Teres minor: Hornblower’s Sign
  • Biceps tendon: Speed’s Test

 

Option C) Adhesive Capsulitis: Adhesive capsulitis is characterized by inflammation and fibrosis of the shoulder capsule, leading to significant restriction of range of motion. Symptoms include gradual onset of shoulder pain, significant limitation in both active and passive range of motion. Commonly affects patients aged 40-60 and can be associated with diabetes. Examination shows limited range of motion in all directions (especially external rotation). Imaging typically shows no structural abnormalities, although MRI may show changes in the joint capsule.

 

Option D) Glenohumeral Instability: Glenohumeral instability refers to excessive movement of the humeral head in relation to the glenoid cavity, often due to trauma or repetitive overhead activities. Symptoms include pain during specific activities, often accompanied by a feeling of the shoulder "giving way." There is a possible history of dislocation or subluxation. Special tests like the apprehension test and relocation test are often positive. Imaging may show structural changes like labral tears.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Shoulder impingement syndrome reflects irritation of the rotator cuff tendons due to mechanical impingement, especially during overhead activities, and requires appropriate management to relieve symptoms and restore function.

questions.text: A patient presents with knee pain and a limp. Radiographs showed the following findings. What is the most likely condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE)

 

Option C)

 

  • During a period of rapid growth, due to weakening of upper femoral physis and shearing stress from excessive body weight, there is upward and anterior movement of femoral neck on the capital epiphysis.
  • So the epiphysis is located primarily posteriorly and medially relative to the femoral neck, although neck moves but the epiphysis does not.
  • SCFE is a condition where the femoral head slips off the neck of the femur at the growth plate, typically occurring in adolescents.
  • Slip occurs through hypertrophic zone of growth plate.
  • It is seen in adolescent children (boys aged 13-15 years and girls aged 11-13 years).
  • Slipping usually occurs as a series of minor events rather than a sudden, acute episode.
  • Symptoms may develop acutely or insidiously.
  • Symptoms:
  • Hip or knee pain, often with a limp.
  • Limited internal rotation of the hip on examination.
  • Patient with unstable acute or acute on chronic SCFE characteristically present with sudden onset of severe, fracture like pain usually as a result of a relatively minor fall or twisting injury.
  • X-rays show a characteristic "slip" of the femoral head relative to the neck.
  • The growth plate appears widened due to displacement.
  • A line drawn tangential to superior femoral neck (Klein’s line) on AP view x-ray will intersect a portion of the lateral capital epiphysis normally.
  • With typical posterior displacement of capital epiphysis, this line will intersect a smaller portion of the epiphysis or not at all. This is called as Trethowan’s sign.

 

 

 

  • Steel’s metaphyseal sign is a crescent-shaped area of increased density overlying metaphysis adjacent to physis (on AP view).
  • It is due to overlapping of femoral neck and posteriorly displaced capital epiphysis.
  • A frog leg’s lateral view is best for detecting mild slip.

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Osteosarcoma: Osteosarcoma is a bone cancer that commonly occurs in the long bones, particularly around the knee. Symptoms include localized bone pain, often worsening over time, swelling or a palpable mass, possible pathological fractures. It typically occurs in adolescents and young adults. Radiographs may show a lytic lesion or a mass around the affected bone. The periosteal reaction is seen as codman’s triangle (triangular bony growth seen at angle of lifting of periosteum) or sunray appearance (calcification along the Sharpey’s fibers) on the x-ray. MRI or biopsy is often needed for confirmation.

 

 

Option B) Perthes Disease: Perthes disease is an avascular necrosis of the femoral head that occurs in children, typically between ages 4 and 10. Symptoms include gradual onset of hip or knee pain, limping, and limited range of motion. Most frequent symptom is limp that is exacerbated by activity and alleviated with rest.  2nd most frequent complaint is pain. Symptoms may initially be mild but worsen over time. During the very early phase, joint is irritable, so extremes of all movements are diminished and painful. Later, most movements are full, but abduction (especially in flexion) and internal rotation are nearly always limited. When the hip is flexed, it may go into obligatory external rotation (Catterall’s sign) and knee points towards axilla (normally, goes towards midclavicular region). Radiographs may initially show subtle changes before evolving into fragmentation of the femoral head. At first X-ray may seem normal, though subtle changes such as widening of joint space and slight asymmetry of ossification centers are usually present. The classical feature of increased density (sclerosis) of the ossification nucleus occurs later and may be accompanied by fragmentation or crescentic subarticular fracture (best seen in lateral view). The head tends to flatten and enlarge (coxa plana). MRI is the Investigation of Choice.

 

 

Option D) Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis: JIA is a chronic inflammatory condition affecting children, leading to joint inflammation, pain, and stiffness. Symptoms include persistent joint pain and swelling, often with morning stiffness. It can affect one or multiple joints, including the knee. There may be systemic symptoms such as fever and rash in certain subtypes. Clinical examination reveals swelling and tenderness in affected joints. Lab tests may show inflammation markers (e.g., elevated ESR, CRP). X-rays can show joint damage or erosions over time.

 

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) is the diagnosis based on the given x-ray image where the femoral head has slipped off the neck of the femur at the epiphysis.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with severe heel pain, especially with the first steps in the morning. On examination, there is tenderness at the plantar fascia insertion. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Plantar fasciitis

 

Option A)

 

  • Plantar fasciitis is an inflammatory condition of the plantar fascia, a thick band of tissue that runs across the bottom of the foot and connects the heel bone to the toes.
  • Symptoms:
  • Sharp heel pain, particularly with the first steps in the morning or after prolonged periods of sitting.
  • Pain may decrease with activity but can return after prolonged standing or walking.
  • Tenderness at the medial aspect of the heel, where the plantar fascia attaches to the heel bone.
  • Clinical diagnosis is made based on history and physical examination.
  • Imaging (such as ultrasound or MRI) is usually not required unless there is suspicion of a more serious condition.

 

Other options:

 

Option B) Achilles Tendinitis: Achilles tendinitis involves inflammation of the Achilles tendon, which connects the calf muscles to the heel bone. Symptoms include pain along the back of the heel, particularly during activities like running or jumping, stiffness and swelling around the tendon, especially in the morning. Pain may improve with activity but worsen with excessive use. Clinical examination reveals tenderness along the tendon and possibly thickening of the tendon. Imaging may help rule out tears or degeneration.

 

Option C) Tarsal Tunnel Syndrome: Tarsal tunnel syndrome is a compression neuropathy of the posterior tibial nerve as it passes through the tarsal tunnel. Symptoms include pain, numbness, or tingling in the sole of the foot, particularly around the arch and heel. Symptoms may worsen with activity and improve with rest. Pain is often described as a burning sensation. Physical examination may show symptoms along the course of the nerve, and Tinel’s sign may be positive. Nerve conduction studies can confirm the diagnosis.

 

Option D) Heel Spur: A heel spur is a bony growth (osteophyte) on the underside of the heel bone (calcaneus) that can develop in response to chronic plantar fasciitis. Symptoms include heel pain that may be associated with plantar fasciitis. However, heel spurs themselves can be asymptomatic and often do not cause pain unless associated with inflammation. X-rays may reveal the presence of a heel spur, but they are often found incidentally in patients with plantar fasciitis.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The given symptoms of heel pain on keeping the first step in the morning and tenderness on the insertion of the plantar fascia is characteristic of plantar fasciitis.
  • Plantar fasciitis is common and often responds well to conservative treatment measures such as stretching exercises, orthotics, and anti-inflammatory medications.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most convenient method for treatment of fracture shaft femur in children less than 2 years of age?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Spica

 

  • A spica cast is a type of cast that immobilizes the hip and thigh and is used to treat fractures of the femur in young children. 
  • The cast typically extends from the chest down to the foot or knee, depending on the location of the fracture.
  • In children under 2 years of age, spica casting is the treatment of choice for femoral shaft fractures. 
  • It is non-invasive, does not require surgery, and provides sufficient immobilization for the bone to heal. 
  • This method is effective, convenient, and associated with fewer complications compared to other methods.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Open Reduction and Internal Fixation (ORIF): This is a surgical technique where the fractured bone fragments are realigned and then stabilized internally using plates, screws, or rods. Typically indicated for complex or unstable fractures, particularly in older children or adults. In children under 2 years, ORIF is usually avoided due to the potential for complications, such as growth disturbances and the risks associated with surgery. This method is more invasive and requires careful management of post-operative care. Generally, not considered convenient or appropriate for this age group unless absolutely necessary due to its invasive nature.

 

Option C. Gallows traction: Gallows traction involves placing weights on a pulley system to apply a longitudinal force to the leg, pulling the femur into alignment. This traction is typically used in the treatment of fractures of the femur in infants and young children. While gallows traction is effective in certain circumstances (especially in very young children), it is not as commonly used today for femoral shaft fractures as spica casting. It is more cumbersome and requires prolonged hospitalization and monitoring, making it less convenient than spica casting.

 

Option D. External Fixation: This method uses external devices attached to the bone via pins or screws to stabilize a fracture. Typically reserved for more complex fractures or in cases where internal fixation is not feasible. While effective in certain situations, it is less commonly used for simple femoral shaft fractures in very young children. It carries risks such as pin site infections and complications associated with having external hardware. Not the first choice for simple femoral shaft fractures in children under 2 years due to its invasive nature and associated risks.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Spica Casting is the most appropriate, non-invasive, and convenient method of treatment. 
  • It provides sufficient immobilization and allows the bone to heal effectively with minimal risk of complications.
