questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with sudden onset of severe pain in his big toe, along with redness and swelling. He has a history of hyperuricemia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gout

 

Option B)

 

  • Gout is an inflammatory arthritis caused by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals in joints and periarticular tissues, with recurrent attacks of acute synovitis due to elevated levels of uric acid in the blood (hyperuricemia).
  • Commoner in men than in women (may be 20:1)
  • Symptoms:
  • Sudden, severe pain in a joint, most commonly the first metatarsophalangeal (MTP) joint (big toe).
  • Redness, swelling, and warmth in the affected joint.

 

 

 

  • Often described as excruciating, with the pain worsening at night or with minor movements.
  • Tophi (nodular deposits of monosodium urate monohydrate crystals) gets deposited in minute clumps in connective tissues.
  • Tophi may ulcerate through skin or destroy cartilage and periarticular bone
  • Attacks can be triggered by factors like alcohol consumption, certain foods (high in purines), stress, or dehydration.
  • Joint fluid analysis can reveal needle-shaped urate crystals under polarized light microscopy, confirming the diagnosis.
  • Elevated serum uric acid levels may be noted, though they can be normal during an acute attack.
  • X-rays may show chronic changes such as tophi (urate deposits) in advanced cases but are not diagnostic in acute settings.

 

 

  • During acute attack, X-rays show only soft tissue swelling.
  • Chronic gout may result in joint space narrowing and secondary OA.
  • Tophi appear as characteristic punched out cysts or deep erosions with over hanging bony edges (Martel’s or G’ sign).
  • These well-defined erosions are larger and slightly further from joint margin than typical RA erosions.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Osteoarthritis: Osteoarthritis (OA) is a degenerative joint disease resulting from the wear and tear of cartilage and underlying bone, often associated with aging or repetitive joint use. Symptoms include pain that is worse with activity and improves with rest, stiffness that lasts for < 30 minutes, commonly occurring in the morning or after periods of inactivity. Involvement of weight-bearing joints (e.g., hips, knees) and often the distal interphalangeal joints of the fingers. It typically does not present with acute swelling and redness. X-rays show joint space narrowing, subchondral sclerosis, osteophyte formation, and sometimes bone cysts. The diagnosis is primarily clinical based on history and physical examination findings.

 

 

Option C) Pseudogout: Pseudogout, or calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate (CPPD) crystal deposition disease, is characterized by the accumulation of calcium pyrophosphate crystals in the joint. Symptoms include sudden onset of joint pain and swelling, often affecting the knees but can involve other joints, including the big toe.

 

 

Symptoms can mimic gout but may be less intense and can occur in multiple joints. Joint fluid analysis shows rhomboid-shaped calcium pyrophosphate crystals under polarized light microscopy.

 

 

X-rays may show chondrocalcinosis (calcification of cartilage) but may not show significant findings in the acute phase.

 

 

 

Option D) Septic Arthritis: Septic arthritis is an infection within a joint, typically bacterial, and can occur after trauma or in patients with pre-existing joint disease. Symptoms include sudden, severe joint pain with swelling, redness, and warmth. Systemic symptoms may include fever, chills, and malaise. Patients often exhibit significant limitation in range of motion due to pain. Joint fluid analysis shows a high white blood cell count, often with a predominance of neutrophils, and cultures may reveal the infecting organism. Imaging (such as ultrasound or MRI) may be used to assess the joint for effusion or abscess.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Gout often requires prompt management to alleviate pain and prevent further episodes, typically involving NSAIDs, colchicine, or corticosteroids. Long-term management includes lifestyle modifications and medications to lower uric acid levels if hyperuricemia persists.

questions.text: Supracondylar fracture of the femur commonly injures which of the following structure?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Popliteal Vessel

 

Option C)

 

  • The popliteal artery and vein run through the popliteal fossa behind the knee.
  • The popliteal artery is a continuation of the femoral artery and is crucial for supplying blood to the lower leg and foot.
  • Supracondylar fractures can lead to direct injury to the popliteal vessels, either through fracture fragments or from swelling and hematoma formation.
  • Vascular injury is one of the most serious complications in such fractures.
  • Injury to the popliteal artery can lead to ischemia of the lower leg, presenting as pale, cold extremities, delayed capillary refill, and possibly necrosis of tissues if blood supply is compromised.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Sciatic Nerve: The sciatic nerve is the largest nerve in the body, originating from the lower lumbar and sacral plexus. It runs down the posterior aspect of the thigh and branches into the tibial and common peroneal nerves. While the sciatic nerve can be injured in fractures of the femur, it is typically more associated with proximal femoral fractures (like intertrochanteric fractures) rather than supracondylar fractures. Its anatomical location makes it less vulnerable in the case of a supracondylar fracture. Damage to the sciatic nerve can lead to motor and sensory deficits in the posterior thigh and lower leg, resulting in weakness of knee flexion and foot drop.

 

Option B) Popliteal Nerve: The popliteal nerve is a continuation of the sciatic nerve that travels down the posterior aspect of the knee and innervates the muscles in the back of the leg and parts of the knee joint. The popliteal nerve can be injured in supracondylar femur fractures, especially if there is significant displacement or swelling in the area. The nerve's position makes it susceptible to direct trauma or compression from hematoma formation. Injury to the popliteal nerve can result in weakness in plantar flexion and toe flexion, as well as sensory loss in the posterior leg and sole of the foot.

 

Option D) Femoral Vessel: The femoral artery and vein run in the groin area and down the thigh, providing blood supply to the upper leg. They are positioned more medially than the popliteal vessels. While femoral vessel injuries can occur with proximal femoral fractures, they are less commonly associated with supracondylar fractures of the femur due to the location of the fracture and the relative protection provided by surrounding structures. Injury to the femoral vessels can cause significant bleeding and swelling in the thigh and groin area, leading to a hematoma or potentially life-threatening hemorrhage.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • While the popliteal nerve can also be injured, the risk of vascular injury, particularly to the popliteal artery and vein, is a significant concern due to the fracture's location and the potential for complications such as ischemia.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with wrist pain after falling on an outstretched hand. An X-ray reveals a fracture at the distal radius with dorsal angulation. What is this type of fracture called?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Colles fracture

 

Option B)

 

  • A Colles fracture is a common type of wrist fracture involving the distal radius, characterized by dorsal angulation and often dorsal displacement of the distal fragment.
  • It typically occurs due to a fall on an outstretched hand (FOOSH injury), where the wrist is in extension.
  • Patients may present with wrist pain, swelling, and a visible deformity (often described as a "dinner fork" appearance).

 

 

 

  • The X-ray shows a fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation, confirming the diagnosis.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Smith Fracture: A Smith fracture, also known as a reverse Colles fracture, is characterized by a fracture of the distal radius with palmar (volar) angulation of the distal fragment. It typically occurs when a person falls onto a flexed wrist or sustains a direct blow to the wrist. The wrist may appear deformed with the palm facing upward.

 

 

Patients usually experience pain and swelling around the wrist. The X-ray shows a fracture of the distal radius with the distal fragment tilted towards the palm.

 

 

Option C) Scaphoid Fracture: A scaphoid fracture involves the scaphoid bone and is often at the waist of the bone. Like the Colles fracture, it usually occurs due to a fall on an outstretched hand. However, it may occur even with less force than is required for a Colles fracture. Patients may report pain in the anatomical snuffbox and may have difficulty gripping or pinching. Scaphoid fractures may not always be visible on initial X-rays; sometimes, follow-up imaging or an MRI is necessary for diagnosis due to the risk of avascular necrosis if not treated promptly.

 

 

Option D) Chauffeur's Fracture: A Chauffeur's fracture involves the fracture of the radial styloid process. This type of fracture occurs due to a direct impact or a fall on an outstretched hand with an additional force, often when gripping something tightly. Patients may experience pain at the wrist, especially over the radial side, with swelling and limited motion. The X-ray reveals a fracture at the base of the radial styloid, which may be associated with a fracture of the scaphoid in some cases.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Colles fracture is fracture of lower end of radius at its corticocancellous junction as a result of fall on outstretched hand, with wrist in extension.
  • There is supination, lateral displacement/lateral tilt, impaction (proximal shift), and posterior displacement/posterior tilt (dorsal tilt) – SLIP – of the fracture fragment.
  • Colles fracture is one of the most common upper extremity fractures and requires appropriate management to prevent complications such as malunion or joint stiffness.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with pain and tenderness over the lateral aspect of her elbow, which worsens with gripping activities. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lateral epicondylitis

 

Option B)

 

  • Lateral epicondylitis, or "tennis elbow," involves inflammation of the common extensor tendon at the lateral epicondyle of the humerus.

 

 

 

  • This condition is caused by repetitive extension of the wrist and gripping, common in racquet sports and other activities requiring forearm strength.
  • Patients typically present with pain and tenderness over the lateral aspect of the elbow, exacerbated by gripping activities or wrist extension.
  • They may also experience weakness in grip strength and pain that radiates down the forearm.
  • Diagnosis is based on clinical evaluation, tenderness over the lateral epicondyle, and pain with resisted wrist extension.
  • Special tests, such as the Cozen's test, can further confirm the diagnosis.

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Medial Epicondylitis: Medial epicondylitis, often referred to as "golfer's elbow," is characterized by pain and tenderness on the medial side of the elbow, specifically affecting the common flexor tendon. It usually arises from repetitive flexion activities, such as gripping, throwing, or using hand tools, leading to overuse and strain on the flexor tendons. Patients may report pain and tenderness at the medial epicondyle, pain that radiates down the forearm, and discomfort with activities involving wrist flexion or gripping. Diagnosis is typically clinical, based on symptoms and tenderness at the medial epicondyle, often confirmed by pain during resisted wrist flexion.

 

Option C) Olecranon Bursitis: Olecranon bursitis is inflammation of the olecranon bursa, located at the back of the elbow. It can be acute (due to trauma) or chronic (due to repetitive friction or pressure). Common causes include direct trauma (e.g., falling on the elbow), prolonged pressure (e.g., leaning on the elbow), or inflammatory conditions (e.g., gout or rheumatoid arthritis). Patients typically present with swelling and tenderness over the posterior aspect of the elbow, with limited range of motion if the swelling is significant. Pain is generally not localized to the lateral aspect and does not worsen specifically with gripping. Diagnosis is usually clinical, based on the presence of a swollen bursa. Aspiration may be performed to rule out infection or other underlying conditions.

 

 

 

Option D) Radial Tunnel Syndrome: Radial tunnel syndrome is a condition caused by compression of the radial nerve as it passes through the radial tunnel near the elbow. It may result from repetitive forearm activities, direct trauma, or anatomical anomalies leading to nerve compression. Patients often report pain along the lateral aspect of the elbow, which may radiate down the forearm, but they typically do not have significant motor weakness. Pain may worsen with activities like wrist extension and gripping, but it usually differs from the classic pain experienced in lateral epicondylitis. Diagnosis is based on the clinical presentation and specific tests that reproduce the symptoms, often ruled out with electromyography (EMG) or nerve conduction studies.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Lateral epicondylitis (tennis elbow) is particularly common among individuals engaged in activities requiring repetitive use of the forearm, leading to irritation and inflammation of the extensor tendons.
  • It involves pain and tenderness on the lateral side of the elbow which exaggerates on gripping objects.

choices.text: If patient is > 65 years old with fracture neck of femur
If patient is < 65 years old with fracture neck of femur

questions.text: Hemiarthroplasty with Austin-Moore prosthesis is done for:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) If patient is > 65 years old with fracture neck of femur

 

Option A)

 

  • The Austin-Moore prosthesis is a type of hemiarthroplasty used for patients, particularly older adults, who have sustained a fracture of the neck of the femur.
  • In patients over 65, conservative treatment options may not be ideal due to factors such as reduced bone quality, increased risk of complications, and the overall functional status of the patient.
  • Hemiarthroplasty provides a reliable method for pain relief and improved mobility in this age group.

 

Other options:

 

Option B) If patient is < 65 years old with fracture neck of femur: While younger patients with neck of femur fractures may also undergo surgical intervention, they are more likely to receive an internal fixation procedure (like a dynamic hip screw) rather than a hemiarthroplasty like the Austin-Moore prosthesis. The focus for younger patients is often on preserving the native joint and promoting healing rather than replacing it.

 

Option C) If fracture is intertrochanteric: Intertrochanteric fractures occur in the area between the greater and lesser trochanters of the femur. While these fractures can be treated with various surgical options, including internal fixation, the Austin-Moore prosthesis is primarily indicated for neck of femur fractures rather than isolated intertrochanteric fractures. Therefore, this option does not accurately describe the typical use of the Austin-Moore prosthesis.

 

Option D) If fracture is pertrochanteric: Pertrochanteric fractures are a subtype of intertrochanteric fractures. Similar to intertrochanteric fractures, the Austin-Moore prosthesis is not typically the first-line treatment for these fractures. Instead, surgical fixation methods, such as dynamic hip screws or intramedullary nails, are preferred. This option is not correct for the use of the Austin-Moore prosthesis.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Austin-Moore prosthesis is indicated for older patients with neck of femur fractures, where a hemiarthroplasty approach is beneficial for functional recovery and pain management.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with knee pain and a prominent tibial tuberosity. He plays soccer and has noticed worsening pain with activity. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Osgood-Schlatter disease

 

Option A)

 

  • Osgood-Schlatter disease is an overuse injury characterized by inflammation of the patellar tendon at its insertion point on the tibial tuberosity.
  • It commonly occurs during periods of rapid growth in adolescents, especially those engaged in sports that involve running, jumping, or squatting (like soccer).
  • The repetitive stress on the knee joint causes traction apophysitis, resulting in pain and swelling at the tibial tuberosity.
  • Patients typically present with localized pain and tenderness over the tibial tuberosity, which worsens with activities like running, jumping, or kneeling.
  • The prominence of the tibial tuberosity can be observed due to bone growth and inflammation.
  • Diagnosis is usually clinical, based on history, physical examination, and the characteristic findings.
  • X-rays may be used to rule out other conditions but are often normal.

 

Other options:

 

Option B) Patellar Tendinitis: Patellar tendinitis, often referred to as "jumper's knee," is an inflammation of the patellar tendon. This condition is also associated with repetitive stress and overuse, particularly in sports involving jumping and running. It is common in athletes who perform explosive movements. Patients typically complain of pain at the inferior pole of the patella, which can radiate down the tendon toward the tibial tuberosity. Pain usually worsens with activity and improves with rest. There is usually tenderness just below the patella rather than directly at the tibial tuberosity. Diagnosis is based on clinical history and examination, with specific tenderness over the patellar tendon. Imaging may be used if the diagnosis is unclear.

 

Option C) Meniscal Tear: A meniscal tear refers to an injury of the meniscus, which is the cartilage that acts as a cushion between the femur and tibia in the knee joint. Meniscal tears often occur due to twisting injuries, particularly when the knee is bent and under load. This injury is more common in contact sports or activities involving sudden changes in direction. Symptoms may include knee pain, swelling, stiffness, and a sensation of locking or clicking during movement. However, meniscal tears are less likely to present with a prominent tibial tuberosity. Diagnosis often involves physical examination manoeuvres (like McMurray's test) and imaging studies (MRI) to visualize the tear.

 

Option D) Anterior Cruciate Ligament (ACL) Injury: An ACL injury involves a tear of the anterior cruciate ligament, a key ligament that stabilizes the knee. ACL injuries commonly occur during sports activities involving sudden stops, jumps, or changes in direction. They may happen with or without direct contact. Patients often experience a "pop" at the time of injury, followed by swelling, instability, and difficulty bearing weight. Pain is usually located deep within the knee and is less likely to be associated with tenderness over the tibial tuberosity. Diagnosis is made through a physical exam (Lachman’s test, pivot shift test) and imaging studies (MRI) to confirm the tear.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The prominent tibial tuberosity and the worsening knee pain with activity are characteristic features of this condition, especially in a young athlete.
  • It is important to manage Osgood-Schlatter disease with rest, ice, and modifications in activity to alleviate symptoms, while also considering physiotherapy to strengthen surrounding muscles and improve function.

questions.text: Injury to which region may result in paraplegia?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thoracic spine

 

Option B)

 

  • The thoracic spine consists of 12 vertebrae (T1-T12) and is located in the upper and mid-back.
  • This region protects vital organs and supports the ribcage.
  • Injury to the thoracic spine can result in paraplegia because it affects the nerve signals responsible for controlling the lower limbs.
  • Damage at or below the thoracic level typically results in the loss of function and sensation in the legs, while upper body functions may remain intact.
  • Injury to the thoracic spine region is most directly associated with paraplegia, as injuries in this region specifically disrupt the neural pathways that control the lower extremities.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Cervical Spine: Injuries to the cervical spine can lead to quadriplegia, which is the loss of function in all four limbs (both arms and legs) due to the disruption of signals between the brain and the body. While cervical spine injuries can result in severe functional loss, they do not typically cause paraplegia, as paraplegia specifically refers to the loss of function in the lower limbs.

 

Option C) Lumbar Spine: This region supports much of the body's weight and is critical for movement. Injuries to the lumbar spine can also result in paraplegia, depending on the level of injury. Damage to the lower lumbar region can affect the lower limbs and may result in weakness or paralysis of the legs.

 

Option D) Sacral Spine: This region is involved in the support of the pelvis and lower body. Injury to the sacral spine can lead to loss of function in the legs and lower body. Damage in this area can result in paraplegia or impairments in bladder, bowel, and sexual function due to the involvement of the nerves that control these functions.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Injuries to the thoracic spine most directly result in paraplegia, as they affect the nerve pathways responsible for controlling the lower limbs.

questions.text: Tardy ulnar nerve palsy is commonly seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cubitus Valgus Deformity

 

Option B)

 

  • Cubitus valgus is characterized by an outward angulation of the forearm relative to the humerus.

 

 

 

  • This deformity can result from various factors, including congenital conditions or trauma.
  • Cubitus valgus can lead to increased tension on the ulnar nerve, particularly at the elbow, as it courses around the medial epicondyle.
  • Over time, this increased tension, and potential compression can result in tardy ulnar nerve palsy.
  • This is the most common deformity associated with this condition.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Cubitus Varus Deformity: Cubitus varus, also known as "gunstock deformity," is characterized by an inward angulation of the forearm relative to the humerus when the arm is extended. While cubitus varus can lead to some compression of the ulnar nerve due to changes in elbow mechanics, it is not the classic deformity associated with tardy ulnar nerve palsy.

 

 

Option C) Dinner Fork Deformity: The dinner fork deformity, or Colles' fracture, is a common wrist fracture resulting from a fall on an outstretched hand, characterized by dorsal angulation of the distal fragment. This deformity primarily affects the wrist and distal radius and does not directly impact the ulnar nerve at the elbow. While complications can arise from wrist injuries, the dinner fork deformity is not associated with tardy ulnar nerve palsy.

 

 

Option D) Garden Spade Deformity: The garden spade deformity refers to a type of wrist deformity, often seen in association with Smith’s fracture due to volar displacement of the radius. Similar to the dinner fork deformity, this condition primarily affects the wrist and does not involve the ulnar nerve at the elbow. The mechanisms involved do not lead to tardy ulnar nerve palsy.

 

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Cubitus valgus is the deformity most commonly associated with tardy ulnar nerve palsy due to its effect on the ulnar nerve's course and tension at the elbow.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with lower back pain radiating down his left leg. He reports numbness and tingling in the left foot. Physical examination reveals positive straight leg raise test. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Herniated disc (L5-S1)

 

Option B)

 

  • A herniated disc occurs when the nucleus of an intervertebral disc bulges out through the outer layer, potentially compressing nearby spinal nerves.
  • Herniations often occur due to acute injury, degeneration of the disc, or repetitive stress.
  • The L5-S1 level is particularly common for herniation due to its significant load-bearing role.
  • Patients typically present with lower back pain that radiates down the leg (sciatica), numbness, tingling, or weakness in the foot or leg.
  • The straight leg raise test is often positive, indicating nerve root irritation or compression.
  • Specific symptoms may depend on which nerve root is affected; in L5-S1 herniation, patients may experience pain radiating down the posterior aspect of the leg and into the foot.
  • Diagnosis is usually confirmed through physical examination and imaging studies, such as MRI, showing the herniated disc and nerve root compression.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Osteoarthritis: Osteoarthritis (OA) is a degenerative joint disease characterized by the breakdown of cartilage and underlying bone, commonly affecting weight-bearing joints. In the spine, OA can lead to the formation of osteophytes and degeneration of the intervertebral discs. While OA can cause back pain, it typically does not lead to radicular symptoms or neurological deficits. Instead, pain may be localized to the lower back and worsens with activity or prolonged standing. Stiffness and limited range of motion are also common. Diagnosis is made through clinical history, physical examination, and imaging studies (X-rays or MRI) showing degenerative changes. However, it does not explain the radiating pain and neurological symptoms observed in this patient.

 

Option C) Spinal Stenosis: Spinal stenosis is the narrowing of the spinal canal or nerve root canals, leading to compression of the spinal cord or nerve roots. It can be caused by age-related changes, such as hypertrophy of ligaments, degenerative disc disease, or congenital narrowing. Patients often report back pain and neurogenic claudication (pain or numbness in the legs that worsens with walking and improves with rest). Symptoms are typically bilateral rather than unilateral and may not be sharply localized like in herniated discs. Straight leg raise tests can also be positive, but the pattern of pain may differ from that seen in herniated discs. Diagnosis is confirmed via clinical evaluation and imaging (MRI or CT) to assess the degree of canal narrowing.

 

Option D) Spondylolisthesis: Spondylolisthesis occurs when one vertebra slips forward over another, which can lead to spinal instability and nerve root compression. It can result from a defect in the pars interarticularis (spondylolysis), degenerative changes, or trauma. Patients may experience localized back pain and potentially radicular symptoms if nerve roots are compressed. However, pain is more often localized, and the neurological symptoms may not follow the classic pattern associated with a herniated disc. Symptoms can worsen with extension of the back. Diagnosis is made through clinical examination and imaging studies (X-rays or MRI) showing vertebral displacement.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Herniated Disc (L5-S1) aligns well with the symptoms and examination findings, indicating nerve root involvement due to the herniation.

questions.text: A patient presented to the emergency department after falling on an outstretched hand. On examination, dinner fork deformity can be noticed. What can be a probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Colles fracture

 

Option A)

 

COLLES FRACTURE

 

  • Colles fracture is fracture of lower end of radius at its corticocancellous junction mostly occurring in post-menopausal osteoporotic elderly women; as a result of fall on outstretched hand, with wrist in extension.
  • It is one of the most common fractures in elderly.
  • A Colles Fracture is a complete fracture of the radius bone of the forearm close to the wrist resulting in an upward (posterior) displacement of the radius and obvious deformity called dinner fork deformity.

 

 

  • The fracture originates from a fall on the outstretched hand and is usually associated with dorsal and radial displacement of the distal fragment, and disturbance of the radial-ulnar articulation.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Carpal tunnel syndrome. It is entrapment of median nerve at the wrist beneath the flexor retinaculum. Its etiology is idiopathic (most common). It can occur due to endocrinal disorders like hypothyroidism, diabetes mellitus, hyperparathyroidism. Other causes includes pregnancy, rheumatoid arthritis, gout, amyloidosis, alcoholism, sarcoidosis. Malunited fractures like Colles fracture is also one of the cause of carpal tunnel syndrome. It is more common in women around 50 years of age. There is no definite deformity present in the condition. The patient presents with burning pain, paresthesia, tingling and numbness in the

distribution of median nerve. Pain is increased by activities, most troublesome in night and relieved by hanging the arm over the side of bed, or shaking the arm.

 

 

Option C. Osteoporosis. Osteoporosis is reduction in bone mass (density) i.e. there is quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has qualitatively normal configuration. The most common presentation is asymptomatic (Calcium is normal). Early, detectable signs of bone loss are rare. Often patients don’t know they have weak bones until there is a fracture of hip, wrist, or spine. In case of fracture of the spine, there is compression of the vertebral body, found on a radiograph as codfish appearance, diagnosing osteoporosis. Colles fracture is one of the most common manifestation of osteoporosis if the patient experiences fall on an outstretched hand.

 

 

Option D. Smith fracture. A Smith fracture is a distal radius fracture with volar displacement or angulation. This injury typically results from a fall on the dorsum of the hand with a flexed wrist. This condition is also known as a reverse Colles fracture since the more common Colles fracture features a dorsally displaced distal fracture fragment. Smith fractures comprise approximately 5% of all radial and ulnar fractures combined, with the highest incidence in young men and older women.  

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The given image and the described dinner fork deformity is diagnostic of colles fracture.
  • Falling on an outstretched hand is the cause of the fracture and the associated deformity.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with hip pain and a limp after running long distances. Physical examination reveals a positive Trendelenburg sign. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gluteus medius weakness

 

Option A)

 

  • The gluteus medius muscle is located on the lateral aspect of the hip, and it is primarily responsible for hip abduction and stabilization of the pelvis during activities such as walking or running.
  • Weakness in the gluteus medius can arise from several factors, including overuse, prior injury, or muscle imbalances.
  • Running long distances can exacerbate underlying weakness or tightness in this muscle.
  • Patients with hip abductor weakness typically present with hip pain, a limp, and a positive Trendelenburg sign.
  • The Trendelenburg sign indicates that the pelvis drops on the contralateral side when standing on the affected leg, reflecting the inability of the gluteus medius to stabilize the pelvis.

 

 

 

  • Diagnosis is made through physical examination, assessing strength and stability of the hip.
  • A positive Trendelenburg sign strongly supports hip abductor weakness, particularly in a patient with a history of increased physical activity.

 

Other options:

 

Option B) Femoral Neck Fracture: A femoral neck fracture commonly occurs in older adults or due to significant trauma. These fractures typically result from falls or high-impact injuries but can also occur with repetitive stress in some cases (e.g., in athletes with certain risk factors). Symptoms include hip pain, inability to bear weight, and a shortened and externally rotated limb. Patients may have severe pain with movement. Diagnosis is usually confirmed via X-ray or MRI. Given that this patient can run and does not present with significant acute trauma or inability to bear weight, a femoral neck fracture is less likely.

 

Option C) Avascular Necrosis: Avascular necrosis (AVN) refers to the death of bone tissue due to a lack of blood supply, commonly affecting the femoral head. AVN can occur due to trauma, corticosteroid use, excessive alcohol consumption, or certain medical conditions. Patients typically present with groin pain, which may radiate to the thigh or buttocks, and pain that worsens with weight-bearing activities. There may be gradual onset of pain rather than acute. Diagnosis is made via imaging (X-ray, MRI) showing characteristic changes in the femoral head. While AVN can lead to limping and pain, it does not directly cause a positive Trendelenburg sign.

 

Option D) Labral Tear: A labral tear refers to a tear in the cartilage surrounding the hip joint (the acetabular labrum), which can occur due to trauma, hip dysplasia, or repetitive stress. Labral tears are often associated with activities that involve twisting or pivoting motions, such as running or playing sports. Symptoms include hip pain, a feeling of instability, clicking or locking sensations in the joint, and pain that can radiate to the groin. Limping may occur, but it is not always present. Diagnosis is typically made through MRI or arthroscopy. Although a labral tear can lead to pain and some limping, it does not specifically cause a positive Trendelenburg sign due to gluteus medius weakness.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Hip Abductor Weakness (Gluteus Medius) aligns with the physical examination findings and the history of increased running activity, indicating weakness in the muscle responsible for stabilizing the pelvis during weight-bearing activities.
  • The trendelenberg sign is positive in case of gluteus medius weakness.

choices.text: Median nerve injury
Radial nerve injury
Ulnar nerve injury

questions.text: Knuckle-Bender splint is used for:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ulnar nerve injury

 

Option C.

 

KNUCKLE BENDER SPLINT

 

  • A Knuckle Bender Splint is an extension assist splint to bring mobility to the interphalangeal joints.
  • It is used for ulnar nerve palsy or to assist weak intrinsic muscles.
  • Provides dynamic MP flexion. 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Median nerve injury. In median nerve injury, wrist splint is more commonly used. Knuckle bender can also be used, but not commonly than a wrist splint.

 

Option B. Radial nerve injury. For radial nerve injury, a cock-up splint is used.

 

 

Option D. Erb’s palsy. In brachial plexus injury, aeroplane splint is used.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The knuckle bender splint is used commonly for ulnar nerve injury more than median nerve injury.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presents with a 2-month history of severe pain in his right foot. Physical examination reveals a limited range of motion and a positive Thompson's test. Radiographs show the following. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Calcaneal fracture

 

Option A)

 

  • A calcaneal fracture typically results from high-energy trauma, such as falls from height or motor vehicle accidents.
  • They can also occur from less severe falls in patients with osteoporosis.
  • Patients often present with severe heel pain, swelling, and difficulty bearing weight.
  • A positive Thompson's test indicates possible involvement of the Achilles tendon, although it may not be directly related to the calcaneal fracture itself.
  • The limited range of motion is due to pain and swelling.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed with radiographs showing the fracture pattern and any potential displacement.
  • CT scans may be used for more detailed evaluation, particularly in surgical planning.

 

Other options:

 

Option B) Talus Fracture: A talus fracture usually results from high-impact injuries, such as falls or car accidents. They can also occur from ankle sprains. Symptoms include pain in the ankle, difficulty with ankle movement, and swelling. Limited range of motion can occur, but the pain is typically more localized to the ankle rather than the heel. Radiographs may reveal fractures of the talus, which can be difficult to visualize, and CT scans may be necessary for a clear assessment. The clinical presentation does not correlate with a calcaneal fracture.

 

Option C) Cuboid Fracture: A cuboid fracture can occur from direct trauma, such as a fall or ankle sprain, and are often associated with other injuries (e.g., foot fractures). Symptoms include lateral foot pain, swelling, and difficulty bearing weight. However, pain is usually localized to the midfoot rather than the heel, and a positive Thompson's test would not typically be associated with this type of fracture. Diagnosis is made through radiographs that may show displacement or comminution of the cuboid bone. The specific symptoms and examination findings do not align with this diagnosis.

 

Option D) Navicular Fracture: A navicular fracture often occur in athletes due to stress or acute trauma, such as an ankle sprain or direct impact. Symptoms include midfoot pain, swelling, and difficulty with weight-bearing. Pain is localized to the top of the foot, not the heel, and a positive Thompson's test would not be relevant. Radiographs or CT scans are used to identify fractures of the navicular. The symptoms described do not correspond with a navicular fracture.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Calcaneal Fracture aligns with the clinical presentation and imaging findings, indicating a significant injury to the heel bone.

questions.text: Which of the following nerves is most commonly damaged in the injury shown in the radiograph given below?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sciatic Nerve

 

Option B)

 

  • The sciatic nerve is the largest nerve in the body, arising from the lumbosacral plexus (L4-S3) and innervating the posterior compartment of the thigh, as well as the entire lower leg and foot via its branches (tibial and common peroneal nerves).
  • The sciatic nerve is commonly injured in hip dislocations, posterior hip fractures, or when there is significant trauma to the pelvis or proximal femur.
  • It can also be affected by herniated discs in the lumbar region.
  • Damage can lead to weakness in hip extension and knee flexion, as well as sensory loss in the posterior thigh, lateral aspect of the leg, and foot.
  • This is the most commonly damaged nerve in injuries involving the hip or proximal femur, making it a likely choice for the scenario.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Deep Peroneal Nerve: The deep peroneal nerve (or deep fibular nerve) branches from the common peroneal nerve and innervates muscles in the anterior compartment of the leg, responsible for dorsiflexion of the foot and toe extension. It is commonly injured in fractures of the fibula or in cases of compartment syndrome in the anterior compartment of the leg. Injury to this nerve can lead to foot drop (inability to dorsiflex the foot) and loss of sensation in the web space between the first and second toes. While this nerve can be damaged in specific lower leg injuries, it is not the most common nerve injured in pelvic or proximal femur fractures.

 

Option C) Femoral Nerve: The femoral nerve arises from the lumbar plexus (L2-L4) and innervates the anterior compartment of the thigh, responsible for knee extension and hip flexion. It can be injured in cases of pelvic fractures, particularly those involving the iliac wing or acetabulum, or in conditions causing compression such as hematoma formation. Injury leads to weakness in knee extension and loss of sensation in the anterior thigh and medial aspect of the leg. While significant, femoral nerve injuries are less common compared to sciatic nerve injuries in traumatic hip injuries.

 

Option D) Saphenous Nerve: The saphenous nerve is a branch of the femoral nerve and provides sensory innervation to the medial aspect of the leg and foot. This nerve can be injured during surgical procedures on the knee or due to trauma, but it is less commonly injured in acute traumatic injuries like fractures. Damage results in sensory loss along the medial aspect of the leg and foot. This nerve is less frequently involved in major traumatic injuries compared to the sciatic nerve.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Sciatic Nerve is most commonly damaged in injuries involving the hip or proximal femur, leading to significant motor and sensory deficits.

questions.text: What is the surgical procedure done to repair a torn meniscus in the peripheral one-third region?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Meniscal repair

 

Option B)

 

  • Meniscal repair is a surgical procedure aimed at stitching together a torn meniscus to preserve as much of the cartilage as possible.
  • This procedure is typically performed on tears that are located in the outer (vascular) region of the meniscus, where there is better blood supply, allowing for healing.
  • The repair can be done arthroscopically, using specialized instruments to place sutures in the meniscus.
  • Meniscal repair aims to restore the normal function of the meniscus, reduce the risk of future joint degeneration, and improve long-term outcomes.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Meniscectomy: Meniscectomy is a surgical procedure involving the partial or complete removal of the meniscus. This procedure is typically indicated when the meniscus is irreparably damaged or when a tear is causing significant symptoms such as pain and swelling that do not respond to conservative treatments. A partial meniscectomy removes only the damaged portion of the meniscus, while a total meniscectomy removes the entire meniscus. While it can relieve symptoms, removing part or all of the meniscus can lead to increased stress on the knee joint and potentially contribute to the development of osteoarthritis over time.

 

Option C) ACL Reconstruction: Anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) reconstruction is a surgical procedure that replaces a torn ACL with a graft, which can be taken from the patient (autograft) or a donor (allograft). This procedure is indicated in cases of ACL tears, especially in active individuals who want to return to high-level sports or activities that involve pivoting. While ACL injuries often occur alongside meniscus tears, ACL reconstruction specifically addresses the ligament and does not directly repair the meniscus itself. Successful ACL reconstruction can restore knee stability and function, but it does not treat meniscal tears unless performed in conjunction with a meniscal repair or meniscectomy.

 

Option D) Total Knee Replacement: This procedure is typically reserved for patients with severe knee arthritis or joint damage that significantly impairs function and quality of life. While TKR can address pain and dysfunction related to meniscal damage as part of broader knee degeneration, it is not specifically a procedure to repair a torn meniscus. TKR can lead to significant pain relief and improved function but is a more invasive option and is typically considered only after conservative treatments have failed.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Meniscal repair involves surgically repairing a torn meniscus by suturing the torn portions of the meniscus.
  • Meniscectomy is also related to meniscus treatment; it involves removal rather than repair.
  • ACL reconstruction and total knee replacement address different knee issues and are not specific to meniscal tears.

questions.text: Name the procedure done to treat a herniated disc?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Discectomy

 

Option B)

 

  • A discectomy is a surgical procedure specifically aimed at removing part or all of a herniated disc that is pressing on spinal nerves.
  • This procedure is indicated when conservative treatments fail to relieve symptoms of severe pain, numbness, or weakness caused by nerve compression.
  • The surgeon may perform a microdiscectomy, a minimally invasive technique where a small incision is made to remove the herniated portion of the disc.
  • This directly alleviates pressure on the affected nerve root.
  • Discectomy can provide significant relief from radicular pain and improve function.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Laminectomy: A laminectomy is a surgical procedure that involves the removal of a portion of the lamina. This procedure is typically performed to relieve pressure on the spinal cord or nerves caused by spinal stenosis. By removing the lamina, the surgeon can access the spinal canal and alleviate nerve compression. Laminectomy can help relieve symptoms such as pain, numbness, and weakness associated with nerve compression. However, it does not directly remove the herniated disk material itself.

 

Option C) Spinal Fusion: Spinal fusion is a surgical procedure that aims to join two or more vertebrae together, eliminating movement between them. This procedure is usually indicated for conditions such as degenerative disc disease, spondylolisthesis, or after discectomy if spinal stability is a concern. While spinal fusion may sometimes be performed after discectomy, it is not primarily a treatment for a herniated disc itself. Rather, it addresses stability issues that may arise post-surgery or from degenerative changes. Spinal fusion can help stabilize the spine and reduce pain but may limit range of motion in the fused segment.

 

Option D) Chemonucleolysis: Chemonucleolysis is a non-surgical procedure that involves the injection of enzymes (such as chymopapain) into the nucleus pulposus of the herniated disc to dissolve the herniated material. This procedure is considered for patients who do not benefit from conservative treatments and want to avoid surgery. It is typically used for specific types of herniated discs. Chemonucleolysis can provide relief from pain and symptoms associated with herniated discs, but it is less commonly performed today due to advances in minimally invasive surgical techniques and the potential for complications.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Discectomy, which specifically addresses the removal of herniated disc material to relieve nerve compression.
  • While laminectomy can relieve pressure on spinal structures, it does not directly treat the herniated disc.
  • Spinal fusion is more about stabilizing the spine and is not a direct treatment for a herniated disc.
  • Chemonucleolysis is an alternative treatment method but is less commonly used in current practice.

questions.text: Identify the bone marked in the given foot radiograph.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Navicular

 

Option B)

 

  • The navicular bone is a boat-shaped bone located in the midfoot.
  • It is situated medially between the talus and the cuneiform bones.
  • The navicular is often visible in foot radiographs and serves as an important landmark in the assessment of foot structure and alignment.
  • In a foot radiograph, the navicular appears as a central bone on the medial side, which helps in determining its identity in relation to other bones.

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Talus: The talus is the bone located above the calcaneus and is part of the ankle joint. It articulates with the tibia and fibula. It is situated more medially in the ankle region and is not typically visible in standard foot radiographs unless focused on the ankle.

 

Option C) Cuboid: The cuboid bone is one of the tarsal bones located on the lateral side of the foot, articulating with the calcaneus and the fourth and fifth metatarsals. It is positioned more laterally and is not located in the central region of the foot radiograph.

 

Option D) Cuneiform: The cuneiform bones consist of three bones (medial, intermediate, and lateral) located in the midfoot. They articulate with the navicular and the first three metatarsals. These bones are located just distal to the navicular but can be identified by their specific shapes and arrangements in the radiograph

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Navicular is typically centrally located on the medial side of the midfoot in radiographs and is easily identifiable.

questions.text: All of the following are true about rickets except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hypertonia

 

  • Hypertonia refers to increased muscle tone, leading to stiffness or rigidity in the muscles.
  • While children with rickets may exhibit muscle weakness due to bone deformities and inadequate mineralization, hypertonia is not a typical feature of rickets. 
  • Instead, muscle tone may actually be decreased due to the muscle fatigue associated with supporting weakened bones.
  • The presence of hypertonia suggests other neurological or muscular disorders rather than a direct association with rickets. Thus, this option is incorrect in the context of rickets.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Craniotabes: Craniotabes refers to a softening and thinning of the skull bones, which can lead to indentations. It is commonly seen in infants with rickets. This occurs due to the deficiency of vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate, leading to poor mineralization of the bone. In rickets, the osteoid matrix is laid down but not adequately mineralized, resulting in weakened bone structure. The presence of craniotabes can be an early sign of rickets and indicates systemic issues with bone mineralization.

 

 Option B. Rachitic Rosary: Rachitic rosary is characterized by a prominent, bead-like appearance at the costochondral junctions. This phenomenon occurs due to the overgrowth of the cartilage at these junctions, which is not adequately mineralized in rickets. The resultant growth leads to swelling and the characteristic "rosary" appearance. It serves as a clinical hallmark of rickets, often observable in physical examinations of children with vitamin D deficiency.

 

Option C. Knock-Knees: Knock-knees (genu valgum) is a condition where the knees angle in and touch each other when the legs are straightened. In rickets, weakened bones and abnormal bone growth due to inadequate mineralization lead to changes in leg alignment. The epiphyseal plates do not close properly, causing deformities as weight-bearing stresses the bone. Knock-knees can be a common manifestation of rickets in children, and addressing underlying nutritional deficiencies can often correct this alignment issue over time.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Hypertonia is not typically associated with this condition. 
  • Rickets primarily involves issues with bone mineralization and growth, leading to deformities and characteristic signs, but not increased muscle tone.

choices.text: Immediate surgical debridement and fixation
Conservative management with antibiotics and pain medication

questions.text: A 20-year-old male sustains a gunshot wound to the right humerus, resulting in a segmental fracture. What is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Immediate surgical debridement and fixation

 

Option A)

 

  • This involves surgically removing any devitalized tissue, debris, and foreign material (like bullet fragments) from the wound, followed by stabilizing the fracture using internal or external fixation methods.
  • Immediate surgical intervention is critical in the case of gunshot wounds to prevent infection, promote proper healing, and ensure better alignment of the fractured bone.
  • Prompt fixation helps stabilize the fracture and restore function, especially in segmental fractures, where the bone is fragmented.
  • This approach is indicated in high-energy injuries such as gunshot wounds, where the risk of infection is significant, and stabilization is essential for recovery.

 

Other options:

 

Option B) Delayed Surgical Fixation: This option would involve postponing surgical intervention for stabilization of the fracture until the patient is more stable or until inflammation subsides. While delayed fixation can be appropriate in some cases of fracture (especially in cases of significant swelling or soft tissue injury), it is not ideal for gunshot wounds. Delaying treatment increases the risk of complications, such as infection and malunion, and may lead to poorer functional outcomes. This is typically reserved for cases where the initial surgical intervention may be too risky due to other injuries or the patient's overall condition.

 

Option C) Conservative Management with Antibiotics and Pain Medication: This approach focuses on non-surgical management, involving the use of pain relief medications and antibiotics to prevent infection without any surgical intervention. While conservative management can be effective for certain types of fractures, it is not suitable for a segmental fracture from a gunshot wound. This type of injury often requires surgical intervention to ensure proper healing and function. This method may be considered in cases of stable, non-displaced fractures, but it is inappropriate for high-energy injuries like gunshot wounds, which typically require more aggressive management.

 

Option D) Amputation: Amputation is considered a last resort and is typically reserved for cases where the limb is severely damaged beyond repair or when there is significant vascular compromise or infection that cannot be controlled. This option would not be appropriate for a segmental fracture unless there is overwhelming evidence that the limb cannot be salvaged or if life-threatening conditions arise from the injury.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Immediate surgical debridement and fixation approach is essential for managing a gunshot wound with a segmental fracture of the humerus, as it addresses the need for both infection control and fracture stabilization.

choices.text: Congenital vertical talus

questions.text: What is the most common congenital deformity of the lower limb?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Clubfoot

 

Option A)

 

  • Clubfoot, or congenital talipes equinovarus (CTEV), is a deformity characterized by Equinus of ankle, inversion of foot, adduction of fore foot and medial rotation of tibia.

 

 

  • It affects the muscles, tendons, and bones of the foot and ankle.
  • It is the most common congenital deformity of the lower limb, occurring in approximately 1 in 1,000 live births.
  • The exact cause is often unclear, but it can be associated with genetic factors and can occur bilaterally.
  • Treatment typically involves a combination of stretching, casting, and, in some cases, surgery to correct the positioning of the foot and improve function.

 

Other options:

 

Option B) Congenital Vertical Talus: Congenital vertical talus is a rare deformity where the talus bone is positioned vertically, leading to a flat foot appearance and a characteristic rocker bottom foot.

 

 

It is often associated with other musculoskeletal conditions and syndromes. This condition is much less common than clubfoot and occurs in a small percentage of live births. It is considered a more complex deformity that may require surgical intervention early in life for correction. Treatment often involves surgery, particularly when conservative measures (like casting) are insufficient to achieve functional foot positioning.

 

Option C) Tarsal Coalition: Tarsal coalition refers to an abnormal connection (fusion) between two or more bones in the midfoot or hindfoot, typically the talus and calcaneus. This condition can lead to pain, stiffness, and limited motion in the affected foot. Tarsal coalition is relatively uncommon compared to clubfoot. It is more often diagnosed in adolescents and can be associated with flatfoot deformities. Management may include conservative approaches (such as orthotics and physical therapy) or surgical intervention to relieve symptoms and restore function.

 

Option D) Polydactyly: Polydactyly is a congenital condition characterized by the presence of extra fingers or toes. It can occur in isolation or as part of a syndrome. While polydactyly is one of the more common congenital hand and foot deformities, it is still less common than clubfoot when specifically considering lower limb deformities. Treatment often involves surgical removal of the extra digits, especially if they cause functional issues or cosmetic concerns.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Clubfoot is the most common congenital deformity of the lower limb, with a significant incidence compared to the other listed conditions.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presented after a motor vehicle accident to the emergency. On examination, the right lower limb was longer than the left, abducted and externally rotated. What can be the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anterior hip dislocation

 

ANTERIOR HIP DISLOCATION

 

  • Anterior dislocations occur with the hip externally rotated and abducted.
  • The degree of flexion at the time of injury determines the eventual position of the femoral head.
  • They are associated with lengthening.
  • Hip dislocations are most common in young adult males and are most often the result of motor vehicle accidents. 
  • The patients present with hip and leg in extension, abduction, and external rotation.

 

 

  • Radiological findings include loss of congruence of femoral head with acetabulum, disruption of shenton's line, femoral head appears larger than contralateral femoral head, and femoral head lies medial or inferior to acetabulum.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Femoral nerve injury: Femoral nerve damage can occur from an injury or prolonged compression. Typically, damage and dysfunction of the femoral nerve are associated with the leg weakness and sensation changes. Injury of the femoral is uncommon but may be injured by a stab, gunshot wounds, or a pelvic fracture. It can also be damaged during hip replacement, abdominal, and pelvic surgeries. The patient presents with poor flexion of the hip because of paralysis of the iliacus, psoas and sartorius muscles. There is an inability to extend the knee because of paralysis of the quadriceps femoris. There is sensory decline over the anterior and medial aspects of the thigh, medial side of the leg and foot up to the first metatarsophalangeal joint. It does not directly affect the position of the hip or the length appearance of the limb.

 

Option B. Femoral neck fracture: Femoral neck fractures are a specific type of intracapsular hip fracture. The junctional location makes the femoral neck prone to fracture. It is commonly seen in the elderly due to low energy falls, and in young patients who perform athletics or due to high-energy trauma. The patient complains of pain with a decreased range of motion of the hip. In non-displaced fractures, there may be no deformity. However, displaced fractures may present with a shortened and externally rotated lower limb. The leg appears shortened due to the upward movement of the distal fragment. The key feature is the inability to bear weight and immediate pain.

 

 

Option C. Posterior hip dislocation: It is the Most common hip dislocation (90%). Patients with a posterior dislocation of the hip generally present with a shortened, internally rotated, adducted limb in slight flexion. If the hip is adducted at the time of injury, a pure dislocation occurs, whereas a neutral position or abduction leads to fracture dislocation. It is associated with a fracture of the femoral head or acetabulum.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The limb appears lengthened and in FABER (flexion, abduction, external rotation) deformity in anterior dislocation of the hip following a motor vehicle accident.
  • Thus, in the given scenario, the patient has anterior dislocation of the hip.

questions.text: Identify the structure pointed in the anatomical snuffbox. (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Extensor pollicis longus

 

Option C) 

 

  • The marked muscle in the anatomical snuffbox is the extensor pollicis longus. 
  • Extensor pollicis longus (EPL) is a long muscle located at the deep layer with extensor pollicis brevis, abductor pollicis longus, extensor indicis, and supinator muscle in the posterior compartment of the forearm. 
  • It originates from the mid-third of the ulna, and interosseous membrane then courses down to the distal phalanx of the thumb. 
  • Though it is situated at the forearm, but it is classified as part of the extrinsic muscles of the hand as its function is seen in thumb movement.

 

ANATOMICAL SNUFFBOX

 

  • The anatomical snuffbox is a triangular depression on the lateral aspect of the wrist and the dorsum of the hand. 
  • It is formed by three tendons of the muscles of the thumb i.e., abductor pollicis longus, extensor pollicis brevis, and extensor pollicis longus. 
  • It is a clinically significant area due to the structures it contains, including the radial artery and the scaphoid bone. 
  • Components of anatomical snuffbox are:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abductor pollicis brevis: The abductor pollicis longus (APL) is one of the extrinsic muscles of the hand. Its major function is to abduct the thumb at the wrist. Its tendon forms the anterior border of the anatomical snuffbox.

 

Option B. Extensor pollicis brevis: The extensor pollicis brevis (EPB) belongs to the deep group of the posterior fascial compartment of the forearm. It is a part of the lateral border of the anatomical snuffbox. This muscle extends the thumb at the MCP and CMC joints. It is also a mild abductor of the thumb.

 

 

Option D. Cephalic vein: The cephalic vein arises as a convergence of superficial veins on the dorsum of the hand in the anatomical snuffbox. From there it runs along the surface just above the radial styloid process. Just beneath the clavicle, the cephalic vein drains into the axillary vein, which bends downwards towards the heart.

 

 

Educational Objective:  

 

  • The marked muscle tendon the given image is of the extensor pollicis longus in the anatomical snuffbox. 
  • It forms the medial boundary of the snuffbox and functions to extend the thumb.

questions.text: Identify the classification used and grade of the shown injury in a child. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gartlands classification Type III

 

The X-ray provided shows a Supracondylar fracture of the humerus, which is classified using the Gartland classification system. The Gartland classification is specifically for supracondylar fractures, particularly in children.

 

  • Gartland Type III refers to a completely displaced fracture, with no cortical contact between the fragments. There may be either medial or lateral displacement, as seen in this case.
  • The Salter-Harris classification is used for epiphyseal plate injuries, not for supracondylar fractures. Therefore, it is not applicable in this scenario.

 

To summarize:

 

  • Gartland Type I: Undisplaced fracture.
  • Gartland Type II: Displaced fracture with the posterior cortex intact.
  • Gartland Type III: Displaced fracture with no cortical contact (either medial or lateral displacement).
  • Gartland Type IV: An intraoperative diagnosis where the periosteum is damaged both anteriorly and posteriorly, requiring more complex reduction techniques.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Salter-Harris classification Type III: Incorrect because the injury in question is not an epiphyseal fracture. Salter-Harris classification is used for growth plate fractures, not supracondylar fractures.

 

Option C. Gartlands classification Type IV: Incorrect because Gartland Type IV is an intraoperative diagnosis, which is not apparent in the provided X-ray.

 

Option D. Salter-Harris classification Type IV: Again, incorrect because this classification system pertains to epiphyseal injuries, and the X-ray shows a supracondylar fracture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Gartland classification is specifically used for supracondylar humerus fractures in children, while the Salter-Harris classification is used for growth plate (epiphyseal) fractures.

 

Gartland classification Supracondylar humerus

 

  • Type 1: Undisplaced
  • Type 2: Displaced with posterior hinge intact
  • Type 3a: Displaced fracture with lateral hinge broken (PM)
  • Type 3b: Displaced fracture with medial hinge broken (PL)
  • Type 4: Completely displaced with both anterior and posterior periosteum avulsed (Intra-operative finding)

 

 

Salter-Harris classification of epiphyseal injuries

 

  • Type I: Fracture line is entirely with in Physis causing epiphyseal slip
  • Type II: Fracture line extends from physis into the Metaphysis (Thurston-Hollands fragment sign)
  • Type III: Fracture line extends from physis into the Epiphysis causing epiphyseal split
  • Type IV: Fracture line extends across the Epiphysis,  (articular surface), Physis, and metaphysis
  • Type V: Crush injury of physis with initially normal X-rays
